did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: Video of ABC News productions with Ted Koppel, including approximately 6,600 episodes of Nightline (Mar 1980-Nov 2005); video and audio media related to production of The Koppel Report; other video content related to Ted Koppel's career
did.langmaterial: Majority is in English, with a few items in Russian, Romanian, French, German, Chinese, and Polish.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Edward James Martin "Ted" Koppel (1940 February 8- ) is an English-born American broadcast journalist, television news anchor and author. He is most known for his twenty-five year tenure as anchor and managing editor of the ABC News program Nightline.

Ted Koppel was born on February 8, 1940 in the town of Nelson in Lancashire, England to German Jewish parents who had fled their home country just prior to the start of World War II. Koppel's father, Erwin Koppel, had owned a tire manufacturing company in Germany, and his mother, Alice Koppel, had been an amateur opera singer. The experience of the war in England and its immediate aftermath had an enduring impact on Koppel, and he has recounted in various contexts the influence the BBC radio rebroadcasts of Edward R. Murrow's war reporting had on his early ambitions to pursue a career in journalism. From 1951-1953, Koppel attended the Abbotsholme School in Staffordshire, England, spending summers and vacations with his parents in Frankfurt, Germany. In 1953, Koppel emigrated with his parents to the U.S.

At the age of sixteen, Ted Koppel enrolled at Syracuse University to pursue a major in Speech and Political Science. During his four years at Syracuse University (1956-1960), Koppel was active as an announcer/disc jockey at the University's radio station WAER and served as the station's Program Director during his senior year (1959-1960). During his final year at Syracuse, Koppel broadcast a self-produced radio report, This is Moscow, comprised of interview clips and commentary collected on a summer trip to Moscow on the occasion of the American Exhibition there. After earning his Bachelor of Science degree from Syracuse University, Koppel attended graduate school at Stanford University studying Mass Communications and Political Science (1960-1962). He was awarded a Master of Arts degree in 1962 with the submission of his graduate thesis, Attitudinal and informational changes precipitated by local newspaper coverage of the Eichmann trial. While at Stanford, Koppel met his future wife Grace Anne Dorney. They were married in 1963, the same year that Koppel became a naturalized U.S. citizen.

After graduation from Stanford, Koppel served a short internship at the NBC network before landing his first job as a copyboy for WMCA radio in New York. A year later, Koppel was hired on at ABC News radio along with Stewart Klein, Charlie Osgood, Betty Adams, Howard Hodkins and former WMCA disc jockey Jim Harriott to staff a new daily news program, Flair Reports. Koppel had only been at ABC News a few months when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated, and one of his first on-air assignments was to stake out the Vice President's residence to solicit comments from Lyndon Johnson. In 1965, Koppel spent several weeks in Selma, Alabama covering the fallout from the Edmund Pettus Bridge incident and the civil rights marches that followed.

Koppel made the shift from radio to television in 1966 when ABC News recruited him to cover the Vietnam War as a foreign television correspondent (1966-1967). While in Vietnam, Koppel produced regular reports for the ABC evening news. In 1968, Koppel returned to the U.S. to cover the Nixon presidential campaign and to serve as Miami Bureau Chief covering Latin American and Cuban affairs. The following year, Koppel was back covering the Vietnam War as Southeast Asia Bureau Chief stationed in Hong Kong (1968-1971). In 1971, Koppel began his first stint as ABC's Chief Diplomatic Correspondent covering Secretary of State William P. Rogers, and then Secretary of State Henry Kissinger through the Watergate years. In this post, Koppel did extensive reporting on China, including traveling with President Nixon on his historic visit to China in 1972. In 1974, Koppel traveled with Henry Kissinger on his shuttle-diplomacy efforts in the Middle East. From 1975-1977, Koppel served as anchor for The ABC Saturday Night News. During a brief hiatus in 1976 while his wife attended law school, Koppel produced daily ABC radio commentaries while collaborating with Marvin Kalb on a novel on Middle East affairs, In the National Interest. In 1978, Koppel produced Second to None, a ground-breaking eleven-part report about US-Soviet military preparedness. That year also saw Koppel return for his second stint covering the State Department (1978-1980).

As Chief Diplomatic Correspondent covering the Carter State Department in late-1979, Koppel was a key figure in ABC's nightly coverage of the ongoing Iran hostage crisis, America Held Hostage (first aired November 8, 1979). In addition to his regular State Department reports, Koppel frequently served as a substitute anchor for the program, periodically relieving Frank Reynolds behind the anchor desk. It was largely the impression he made in this role that influenced then president of ABC News Roone Arledge to select Koppel as the founding anchor for the new late-night news program, Nightline (first aired March 24, 1980). Evolving out of the Iran hostage update program, Nightline grew rapidly into a cornerstone of the network's expanding roster of television news programs. For nearly three decades from its inception (1980 -2005), Ted Koppel anchored the innovative late-night show that featured a unique mix of in-depth reporting, extended live interviews (often with multiple participants), and live updates on breaking news stories. In the era before the emergence of the 24 hour cable news cycle, Nightline was often the only conduit for breaking-news between the evening and morning news reports. In addition to creating the mold for the modern televisions news magazine program, Nightline has contributed important innovations to the practice of television journalism including the use of simultaneous live satellite interviews with multiple participants; the use "natural sound" narration (the "Petacque" technique); the town-meeting discussion/debate format; and the use of Hi8 and hand-held video cameras for the collection of original news footage.

In 1987, at the height of Nightline's initial success, Koppel entered into contract negotiations with the ABC network and its parent company at that time, Capital Cities Communications. Part of these negotiations focused on Koppel's desire to establish his own production company, and in March of 1988 ABC News finalized an agreement to assist in the formation of Koppel's new venture, Koppel Communications Inc. (KCI). ABC agreed to air several KCI-produced news specials and documentaries each year (The Koppel Report), as well as allowing Koppel to produce additional programs for independent distribution through other outlets. Such a deal was virtually unprecedented at its time for a network news figure. The Koppel Report, anchored by Ted Koppel and featuring the production talents of a number of his Nightline colleagues, was an award-winning program that saw the production of 11 news programs over three years (1988-1990). Typically in a documentary format, though also including town hall debates, the programs explored in-depth many of the major events of the day. Programs included examinations of the televangelist phenomenon (The Billion Dollar Pie), life in the Soviet Union at the end of the Cold War (Sex in the Soviet Union), the events of the Romanian Revolution (Death of a Dictator), and the Tiananmen Square uprising in Beijing (Tragedy at Tiananmen: The Untold Story).

In 2005, after twenty-five years and with nearly 6,600 episodes under his belt, Ted Koppel decided to move on from his role as anchor and managing editor on Nightline. His last program aired November 22, 2005. Shortly after leaving ABC News, Koppel, former Nightline Executive Producer Tom Bettag, and a group of eight other former Nightline staffers formed a deal with the Discovery Channel to produce a series of news programs and documentaries for cable television. The subsequent Koppel on Discovery (2006-2008) productions included: The Price of Security; Iran: Most Dangerous Nation; Our Children's Children's War; Living with Cancer; Breaking Point; The Last Lynching; and a much acclaimed four-part series on China, The People's Republic of Capitalism. This in-depth exploration of the modern Chinese economy has been singled-out by Koppel as one of his most satisfying documentary achievements.

After 2008, Koppel remained active as a broadcaster, author and speaker, serving as a news analyst for National Public Radio, a contributor to BBC America, and a correspondent for the NBC News program Rock Center with Brian Williams. In addition, Koppel has contributed articles to numerous books and publications, including Forbes, The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal.

In addition to his voluminous broadcast work, Koppel has accumulated a number of writing credits as well. Some of his written works include: In the National Interest (1977, with Marvin Kalb); Nightline: History in the Making and the Making of Television (1996, with Kyle Gibson); Live from the Trenches: The Changing Role of the Television News Correspondent (1998, contributor); Off Camera: Private Thoughts Made Public (2000); Lights Out: A Cyberattack, A Nation Unprepared, Surviving the Aftermath (2015).

Ted Koppel has received numerous awards and recognitions over the course of his long career including: the Edward R. Murrow Lifetime Achievement Award, 41 Emmy awards, eight George Foster Peabody Awards, 10 duPont-Columbia Awards, 10 Overseas Press Club Awards, two George Polk Awards, and 2 Sigma Delta Chi Awards. Koppel was awarded the first Gold Baton (duPont-Columbia Awards) for Nightline's week-long series originating from South Africa, the Gabriel Personal-Achievement Award from the National Catholic Association of Broadcasters and Communicators, and selection as a Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres from the Republic of France. He has received more than 20 honorary degrees from universities in the United States.

[In addition to the material in the Ted Koppel Collection, the following sources were consulted for this biography: Nightline: History in the Making and the Making of Television (Random House, 1996); Off Camera: Private Thoughts Made Public (Vintage, 2001); The House That Roone Built (Little, Brown, 1994); Ted Koppel interview video (conducted by Don Carleton 6/14/2005), Archive of American Television, accessed 10/05/2015 (http://www.emmytvlegends.org/interviews/people/ted-koppel#); Ted Koppel Wikipedia page, accessed 10/08/2015 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Koppel).]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The Ted Koppel Collection contains over 9,000 media items in videotape, audio tape and optical disc formats, as well as over 22,500 digital archival preservation copies of Nightline episodes, The Koppel Report, and other Koppel related content (7,500 archival masters in duplicate and 7,500 viewing copies). The collection also includes over 6,000 Nightline transcripts in digital form.

The vast majority of the collection consists of a comprehensive run of the Nightline program during Ted Koppel's tenure as anchor, 1980-2005. There are approximately 6,600 episodes of Nightline represented in the collection. Virtually all of these episodes are available in digital format, most with accompanying digital text transcripts. Years covered include: 1980, 1981, 1982, 1983, 1984, 1985, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005

The collection also contains several thousand video and audio recordings related to The Koppel Report and other Koppel Communications Inc. productions, including original interviews, field recordings, production materials and broacast masters. The collection contains material related to all eleven episodes of The Koppel Report: The Billion Dollar Pie; The Blue X Conspiracy; DC/Divided City; Death of a Dictator; Drugs, Crime and Doing Time; The Legalization of Drugs/A National Town Meeting: The Legalization of Drugs; News from Earth; Sex in the Soviet Union; Television: Revolution in a Box; A Town Meeting with Nelson Mandela; Tragedy at Tiananmen: The Untold Story.

The collection also includes examples of Ted Koppel's work for the Discovery Networks, Koppel on Discovery, as well as additional ABC News programs and specials including: Viewpoint, Up Close, Nightline in Primetime, and the Jennings Koppel Report. There is additional miscellaneous material related to Ted Koppel interviews, promotional spots and appearance clips. There is also a small sample of Ted Koppel's radio work while a student at Syracuse University and Stanford University, including the report This is Moscow.

altformavail.head: Other Formats Available
altformavail.p: Much (but not all) of the collection has been digitized, and transcripts are available for many (but not all) episodes. More information on available formats in given in the appropriate sections of the inventory below.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: Media is grouped by series and episode. Nightline, Viewpoint and Up Close episodes are listed in chronological order.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.
Digitized media may be accessed at a viewing station in the SCRC reading room.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The programs may be used by students, faculty and researchers in the library and in the classroom for instructional purposes only.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

scopecontent.p: After leaving Nightline in November of 2005, Koppel, Nightline Executive Producer Tom Bettag, and a group of eight other Nightline staffers formalized an agreement with Discovery Networks to produce a series of documentaries and other long-form news programs. Over the course of nearly three years, Koppel and company delivered seven documentaries, including a much acclaimed four-part series on China, "The People's Republic of Capitalism". This in-depth exploration of the modern Chinese economy has been singled-out by Koppel as one of his most satisfying documentary achievements. Other Koppel on Discovery programs include: "The Price of Security"; "Iran: Most Dangerous Nation"; "Our Children's Children's War"; "Living with Cancer"; "Breaking Point"; and "The Last Lynching".

The Ted Koppel Collection contains a few dozen VHS tapes related to two separate Koppel on Discovery documentaries: The Price of Security and The People's Republic of Capitalism. Most of these tapes are post-production rough-cuts, or "screeners", of the four-part China documentary.

Executive Producer: Tom Bettag; Producers: John Alexander, James Blue, Peter Demchuk, Jay Lamonica, Nick Mackie, Elissa Rubin, Alissa Shapiro, Emily Stanitz; Managing Editor: Ted Koppel; Production: The Discovery Channel.
Episodes of the four-part series are: Part 1: Joined at the Hip; Part 2: MAO-ism to ME-ism; Part 3: The Fast Lane; Part 4: It's the Economy Stupid.

The collection contains approximately 26 VHS tapes of various post-production versions of each episode including rough cuts. Most tapes contain 1-2 acts of a particular episode, and there is some duplication.

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Tom Bettag; Producers: James Blue, Peter Demchuk, Richard Harris, Jay Lamonica, Elissa Rubin; Managing Editor: Ted Koppel; Production: Koppel Communications Inc., The Discovery Channel.

This post-9/11 examination of national security policy was Koppel's fist documentary production for Discovery. An original 90 minute documentary was followed by an additional 90 minute town hall segment. Issues such as airport security, detention policy, torture, Guantanamo Bay, NSA mass surveillance are examined in light of the tension between security needs and individual liberties.
The collection contains VHS copies of the documentary portion of the broadcast only. The subsequent town hall debate segment is not included.

This award-winning program, anchored by Ted Koppel and featuring the production talents of a number of Nightline veterans, included eleven episodes over three-years covering such diverse topics as television, religion, human sexuality, crime and punishment, technology, and international politics. Typically in a documentary format, though at times including town hall debates, The Koppel Report explored in-depth many of the major events of the day, and in the process documented not only the primary historical record of events, but also reflected how those events were perceived and contextualized as they happened.

In addition to the Koppel Communications Inc. owned broadcast masters of each report, the collection also contains hundreds of hours of accumulated source video that was utilized in the making of each program. This material includes unedited original footage of complete interviews, field footage of important places and developing events, clip reels of relevant news footage and historical footage, documentaries and original performance material, as well as post-production elements (graphics, effects and audio tracks) and submaster versions of episodes and episode segments.

The collection contains material related to all eleven episodes of The Koppel Report: The Billion Dollar Pie; The Blue X Conspiracy; DC/Divided City; Death of a Dictator; Drugs, Crime and Doing Time; The Legalization of Drugs/A National Town Meeting: The Legalization of Drugs; News from Earth; Sex in the Soviet Union; Television: Revolution in a Box; A Town Meeting with Nelson Mandela; Tragedy at Tiananmen: The Untold Story.

altformavail.p: A large portion of The Koppel Report videotape materials have been digitized (including the final broadcast masters). These items are noted in the inventory below.

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Richard N. Kaplan; Directors: Roger Goodman, Jan Rifkinson; Production: Koppel Communications Inc.

This program explores the phenomenon of Christian television evangelism. The opening segment establishes a contrast between small, grass roots congregations, like the Reverend John Sherfy's congregation, and the large, lucrative ministries of the most popular "televangelists". The decline of religious broadcasting is attributed to the shrinking demographic that has traditionally provided the bulk of the funding (through religious donations) and the proliferation of sexual misconduct scandals, infighting among the ministries and financial corruption. The bulk of the program centers on a town-hall-style panel discussion from the Central Church in Memphis, Tennessee. The discussion focuses on topics such as the corrupting force of big-money on religious broadcasters and Christian ministry in general, the limited growth potential of the audience for religious broadcasting, the impact of high-profile scandals on the biggest television ministries, and the destructive affects of intensive competition among the ministries for a diminishing slice of the revenue pie.

Total media holdings related to this program include approximately 150 items (about 100 hours). The majority of this consists of original footage of churches, church services and interviews with preachers and congregants. The collection also includes clip compilations and dubs of various televangelist productions, as well as the complete original recordings of the televangelist studio debate filmed in Memphis. In addition to a batch of post-production material, there are multiple versions of the final show, including two broadcast masters.

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Phyllis McGrady; Production: Koppel Communications Inc., ABC News, Gosteleradio.

This dramatic staging of a crisis game (war game) featuring high-ranking former and current US and Soviet officials--the first such joint exercise ever conducted--documents the decision making process involved in managing a full-scale international crisis within a late-Cold War context. Two groups of decision makers--one in Washington, the other in Moscow--are presented with a progressively developing hypothetical situation by the program's producers. The hypothetical crisis begins with the announcement of a series of destabilizing attacks against the Soviet-backed government in Afghanistan, and progresses to include a chemical terrorist attack against the President and his cabinet, producing a presidential succession crisis that complicates the US diplomatic and military response.

A near majority of the tapes for this program (90-100) are original footage of the war games and the in-studio footage from multiple cameras at both the US and Moscow locations. There are 25 tapes of US and Moscow Director's cuts of the original footage material. Various clips reels and original location footage (Washington DC, Pentagon, White House, Kremlin, etc.), used for set pieces, consists of 30-40 tapes, while there are around 40-45 tapes of post-production material (music, audio, translations, graphics, dub reels and protection copies). The collection also contains the broadcast master tapes for both US and international distribution.

did.unittitle: The Koppel Report: The Blue X Conspiracy (Safety Master) (1553-89).
The Koppel Report: The Blue X Conspiracy (1" PAL Master) (421).

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Richard N. Kaplan; Director: Roger Goodman; Production: Koppel Communications Inc., ABC News.

The Koppel Report hour-long documentary and follow-up Nightline town hall meeting addresses the complexities of race, drugs, violent crime and economic justice as manifest in Washington, D.C. in the late-1980s. From the program introduction: "this is a special edition of Nightline, DC: Divided City, a National Town Meeting. ... to discuss the relationship between drugs, crime and racism. [Participants include:] police chiefs from Washington, DC and Fairfax County; President's national drug policy adviser; the secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD); the mayors of Washington, DC, Alexandria, Virginia, Annapolis, Maryland; Georgetown University's basketball coach; 12 of 13 members of the DC City Council; representatives of eight federal agencies, HUD, HHS, DEA, Education, Customs, National Guard, US Attorney; heads of community drug programs; three members of Congress; community residents from throughout Washington."

The vast bulk of this material is comprised of original footage ("field betas") including: b-roll, helicopter aerial and location footage from all over the DC area; documentary footage related to various aspects of life in the DC community (crime, violence, church, housing, schools, nightlife, Georgetown University, police relations, drug abuse and treatment, wealth, segregated communities); unedited interview footage with a range of subjects including local leaders, man-on-the-street interviews and interviews with such notables as Kimmi Gray, Cathy Hughes, Marion Barry, Police Chief Maurice Turner, Clifford Alexander, Juan Williams and John Thompson. There is a relatively small amount of post-production material for this program, primarily audio tracks with graphics elements and edit submasters for various segments. There are broadcast masters of The Koppel Report documentary and the Nightline town meeting programs.

did.abstract: Ted Koppel and DC Councilman H.R. Crawford on a night tour of inner-city DC locations. Footage from moving vehicle and at various locations beginning at a public housing complex above the capitol and including Ward 6 and Ward 7 neighborhoods. Discussion focuses on public housing, the local area drug trade, inner-city violence and local history. Associated program: DC/Divided City

Discussion focuses on public housing, the local area drug trade, inner-city violence and local history. Associated program: DC/Divided City

Interview with Georgetown/DC native and local historian Herbert Barksdale. Barksdale details the history of the Georgetown neighborhood and the progressive displacement of black residents from the area. He also addresses some of the fundamental divisions in Washington DC. Associated program: DC/Divided City

Interview with Robert Woodson, Executive Director of the Center for Neighborhood Enterprise. Woodson addresses the displacement of blacks in DC and details some of the fundamental racial and economic divisions in Washington DC. Associated program: DC/Divided City

did.abstract: Interview with afrocentrist psychiatrist Frances Cress Welsing. Welsing examines the fundamental urban problems of DC (drugs, violence, unemployment, housing) in the context of the global phenomenon of racism or what she calls the imperative for white genetic survival. Associated program: DC/Divided City

did.unittitle: Interview with Professor Dennis Gale, George Washington University (DCG 086)
did.abstract: Interview with George Washington University professor Dennis Gale. Gale talks about the unique population structure of DC and how that underlies the core divisions of the city. Gale addresses the history of urban renewal programs in DC in the Southwest neighborhood and Georgetown, the problems inherent in the DC education system, and other problems related to the fundamentally segregated nature of the population. Associated program: DC/Divided City

scopecontent.p: This documentary report on the Romanian Revolution of 1989-1990 provides and authoritative recounting of the tumultuous and at time chaotic events that unfolded in Timisoara, Bucharest and across Romania with the fall of the Ceausescu communist regime. Extensive interviews with key figures and original footage of events on the ground combine with an unprecedented post-Revolution view into the world "behind the curtain" in a Soviet-bloc country at the end of the Cold War. This program won an Emmy and a Peabody Award in 1990.

The vast majority of the tapes associated with this report are original footage, mostly field tapes, from Bucharest and Timisoara, Romania (Jan-Mar 1990). This footage includes many multi-tape interviews with important military and government officials, including Prime Minister Petre Roman; interviews and footage of ordinary Romanian citizens; and footage of demonstrations, the toppling of a Lenin statue and other significant events. In addition, there are many tapes of original news reporting from Romanian and American television sources (RTV and ABC London footage), dubs of international news broadcasts from multiple sources and clip reels of historical/file footage. In addition to the broadcast masters, there is only a very small amount of the typical post- production material present.

did.abstract: Public demonstrations in Bucharest on Sunday, January 28, 1990. Demonstrators carrying flags and signs. MOS interviews [in Romanian] Crowd chanting slogans. Lighting candles at street memorials. Soldiers and tanks line streets
Demonstrations and crowds chanting. Soldiers and tanks line street and public square. View of demonstration at crowd level and elevated.
Graveyard in Bucharest (Young Heroes Cemetery). Old women digging frozen ground with picks and shovels. Mourners lighting candles and scenes of memorials
Demonstrators marching past cemetery (Young Heroes Cemetery). Mourners at graves and scenes of graves
Old women digging with pickaxes in graveyard (Young Heroes Cemetery). People waiting in line to buy newspapers. Close-up of newspaper headlines. People reading newspapers. Street scenes. Pedestrians

Interview with Romanian Army Officer Major Mihai Lupoi [in English] Lupoi discusses events that occurred in Timisoara and at the Tirgoviste military base in late-December 1989. Lupoi describes events relating to General Vasile Milea (and his eventual suicide) and the developing Army response to the demonstrations in Timisoara. Lupoi describes events leading to his televised statement conveying Army support for the revolution and subsequent Army actions in support of the revolution. Lupoi describes Army custody of Ceausescu prior to his trial and execution

Interview with Romanian Army Officer Major Mihai Lupoi [in English] Lupoi discusses events that occurred in Timisoara and at the Tirgoviste military base in late-December 1989. Lupoi describes Army custody of Ceausescu and his trial and execution

Interview with Romanian Dr. Gabriel Tatu [in English] Tatu discusses events that occurred in late-December 1989. Tatu describes the extent and types of casualties treated at his Bucharest hospital Dec. 21-30. Footage of hospital entrance,lobby interior, and exterior scenes (Directia Sanitara A Municipiului Bucuresti)

Interview with Nicolae Teodorescu, defense attorney at the Ceausescu trial [Romanian with English translation] Teodorescu discusses the events of the trial and the execution of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu

did.unittitle: Nicolae Teodorescu Interview Part 2/Dusk Beauty/Exterior Beautys Romanian TV (10) (Rupen No. 10)
did.abstract: Interview with Nicolae Teodorescu, defense attorney at the Ceausescu trial [Romanian with English translation] Teodorescu discusses the events of the trial and the execution of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu. Dusk beauty shots from car. Daytime exterior shots of Romanian TV building, people at checkpoint, soldiers, and armored vehicles.

Interview with Ion Todan of Romanian TV [in English] Todan discusses the events that occurred at the end of December 1989 at the Romanian television studios in Bucharest and the role of Romanian television in the developing events of the revolution

Interview with Ion Todan of Romanian TV [in English] Todan discusses the events that occurred at the end of December 1989 at the Romanian television studios in Bucharest and the role of Romanian television in the developing events of the revolution

Interview with Romanian television correspondent Nicolae Melinescu [in English] Melinescu discusses the transformation of Romanian news reporting since the revolution, the events that occurred at the end of December 1989 at the Romanian television studios in Bucharest, and the role of Romanian television in the developing events of the revolution

Interview with Romanian television correspondent Nicolae Melinescu [in English] Melinescu discusses events that occurred at the end of December 1989 at the Romanian television studios in Bucharest and the role of Romanian television in the developing events of the revolution

Video of still images showing demonstrators, soldiers and Ceausescu. Interview with university professor Dan Andrunescu [Romanian with English translation] Andrunescu discusses the events in Bucharest during late December 1989

Interview with Romanian writer and dissident Mircea Dinescu [Romanian with English translation] Dinescu discusses life under the Ceausescu regime, his past as an opponent of the regime, and the events of late December 1989 related to the revolution

Interview with Romanian writer and dissident Mircea Dinescu [Romanian with English translation] Dinescu discusses life under the Ceausescu regime, his past as an opponent of the regime, and the events of late December 1989 related to the revolution

Interview with Romanian writer and dissident Mircea Dinescu [Romanian with English translation] Dinescu discusses life under the Ceausescu regime, his past as an opponent of the regime, and the events of late December 1989 related to the revolution

Interview with Dan Ciobanu of Romanian television [in English] Ciobanu discusses events in Bucharest on December 21-24, 1989, demonstrations, street fighting, and key events inside of the ministry of defense

did.abstract: Interview with Dan Ciobanu of Romanian television [in English] Ciobanu discusses events in Bucharest on December 21-24, demonstrations, street fighting, and key events inside of the Ministry of Defense. Includes exterior beauty shots of the central committee building in Bucharest. Scenes of pedestrians in Palace Square, buildings damaged in the fighting, and soldiers patrolling the square

Interview with Romanian professor and dissident Dumitru Mazilu [in English] Mazilu discusses his role as an opponent of the Ceausescu regime, the evolution of anti-Ceausescu sentiment in the country, the influence of the Securitatea in Romanian society, and the persecution that he and his family endured as opponents of the regime.

Interview with Romanian professor and dissident Dumitru Mazilu [in English] Mazilu discusses about his response to the revolution, drafting a platform for the revolution (a draft constitution for Romania), and the events surrounding his arrest and detention during the late days of December 1989. Mazilu details the significant points articulated in his program document

did.unittitle: Dumitru Mazilu Interview Part 3/Emil Dumitrescu Interview Part 1 (27) (Rupen No. 42)
did.abstract: Interview with Romanian professor and dissident Dumitru Mazilu [in English] Interview concludes with close-up footage of Mazilu's original handwritten revolution program manuscript. Interview with former Securitate officer Emil Dumitrescu [Romanian with English translation] Dumitrescu discusses the events in Bucharest in late-December 1989 and his involvement in the revolution

Interview with former Securitate officer Emil Dumitrescu [Romanian with English translation] Dumitrescu discusses the events in Bucharest in late-December 1989 and his involvement in the revolution. Dumitrescu describes his role in defending the Bucharest television and radio stations

Interview with former Securitate officer Emil Dumitrescu [Romanian with English translation] Dumitrescu discusses the events in Bucharest in late-December 1989 and his involvement in the revolution. Dumitrescu describes his role in the arrest of Nico and Zoe Ceausescu (children of Nicolae Ceausescu)

Interview with former Securitate officer Emil Dumitrescu [Romanian with English translation] Dumitrescu discusses the events in Bucharest in late-December 1989, his involvement in the revolution, and the role of Romanian television during revolution
Interview with Romanian student demonstrators Ollie Susnea and Viorica Butnariu [in English] Students discuss the events in Bucharest, December 21-25, 1989

did.unittitle: Student Interviews Part 2/Bucharest Beauty Roll (32) (Rupen No. 47).
did.abstract: Interview with Romanian student demonstrator Viorica Butnariu [in English] Butnariu discusses the events in Bucharest, December 21-25, 1989. Interview with Romanian student Adrian [in English] Adrian discusses his experience at the television studio in Bucharest, December 22-23, 1989 and the importance of Romanian television in the revolution. Video ends with beauty shots of daytime street scenes in Bucharest: traffic, pedestrians, building facades

Interview with Romanian communist politician Silviu Brucan [in English] Brucan discusses his past role in the Romanian government, the communist party, and opposition to the Nicolae Ceausescu regime from within the party. Brucan describes Ceausescu's background, his rise to political power, and the events related to the emergence of the revolution

Interview with Romanian communist politician Silviu Brucan [in English] Brucan discusses the formative events in Brasov 1989, his treatment as an opponent to the regime, and the development of political strategy against Ceausescu. Brucan also talks about the creation of the Letter of the Six

Interview with Romanian communist politician Silviu Brucan [in English] Brucan discusses his arrest and interrogation by the Securitate for his role in creating the Letter of the Six as well as the consequences its creation.

Interview with Romanian communist politician Silviu Brucan [in English] Brucan discusses the circumstances of his confinement for the publication of the Letter of the Six, his involvement in the revolution in Bucharest, and his involvement in the events at the television studio and at the Ministry of Defense. Interview include information about Brucan's confrontation with General Vlad

Interview with Romanian communist politician Silviu Brucan [in English] Brucan discusses the confrontation he had with General Vlad at the Ministry of Defense in late December 1989. In response to further questioning, Brucan provides additional details about the scenes inside the Romanian television building when he arrived there. Brucan also provides additional information concerning the confrontation with General Vlad in the Ministry of Defense

Interview with Romanian communist politician Silviu Brucan [in English] Brucan discusses the arrest of General Vlad in the Ministry of Defense, the trial and execution of Ceausescu, and the war council meeting where the fate of Ceausescu was decided. War council consisted of the Executive Bureau of the Front

Interview with Romanian communist politician Silviu Brucan [in English] Brucan discusses his assessment of the Ceausescu trial, the Ceausescu execution, and the political developments in Romania after the revolution, January 1990

did.abstract: Interview with General Ion Mihai Pacepa, defector to the U.S. and former head of the Securitate [in English] Pacepa discusses the rule of Ceausescu and the role of the Securitate in Romanian society.

did.unittitle: Young Heroes Cemetery/Ted Koppel Stand-Up/Beauty Roll/Informal Interviews (57) (Rupen No. B1)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel stand-up in Young Heroes Cemetery (multiple takes). Informal interviews with people in the cemetery

did.unittitle: Young Heroes Cemetery Beauty-Roll Part 1 (58) (Ron No. B1).
did.abstract: Young Heroes Cemetery beauty-roll. Scenes of mourners placing flowers on graves and lighting memorials. Ted Koppel informally interviewing people in the cemetery

did.unittitle: Young Heroes Cemetery Beauty-Roll Part 2 (60) (Ron No. B2).
did.abstract: Young Heroes Cemetery beauty-roll. Women tending to memorials. Scenes of mourners placing flowers on graves and lighting candles next to memorials

did.unittitle: Interview with General Victor Stanculescu (Minister of Defense) Part 1 (61) Rupen No. B3)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interviews Romanian Minister of Defense, General Victor Stanculescu [Romanian with English translation] Stanculescu answers questions about the release of the Securitate's secret files and the disposition of the Securitate in post-revolution Romania

did.unittitle: TK Interview with Gen. Stanculescu, Minister of Defense (Pt. 1) (62)
Interview with General Victor Stanculescu (Minister of Defense) Part 2 (63) (Rupen No. B4)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interviews Romanian Minister of Defense, General Victor Stanculescu [Romanian with English translation]Stanculescu addresses questions about the disposition of the Securitate in post-revolution Romania and the role of investigative commissions. Stanculescu discusses the overall extent of casualties during the revolution, scenes surrounding Ceausescu's escape via helicopter, Ceausescu's arrest, Ceausescu's execution, and his role in these events

did.unittitle: Interview with General Victor Stanculescu (Minister of Defense) Part 2/Ted Koppel Camera View (64) (Ron No. B4)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interviews Romanian Minister of Defense, General Victor Stanculescu [Romanian with English translation]Stanculescu addresses questions about the disposition of the Securitate in post-revolution Romania and the role of investigative commissions. Stanculescu discusses the overall extent of casualties during the revolution, scenes surrounding Ceausescu's escape via helicopter, Ceausescu's arrest, Ceausescu's execution, and his role in these events

did.unittitle: Interview with Prime Minister Petre Roman Part 1/Roman Camera View (65) (Rupen No. B5)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interviews Romanian Prime Minister Petre Roman [in English] Roman discusses concerns about the direction of post-revolution political developments, the upcoming democratic elections, and the emergence of a free press in Romania. Roman also addresses the post-revolution status of the Securitate and the restructuring of the government

did.unittitle: Interview with Prime Minister Petre Roman Part 1/Ted Koppel Camera View (66) (Ron No. B5)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interviews Romanian Prime Minister Petre Roman [in English] Roman discusses concerns about the direction of post-revolution political developments, the upcoming democratic elections, and the emergence of a free press in Romania. Roman also addresses the post-revolution status of the Securitate and the restructuring of the government

did.unittitle: Interview with Prime Minister Petre Roman Part 2/Ted Koppel Camera View (68) (Ron No. B6)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interview with Romanian Prime Minister Petre Roman [in English] Roman discusses the key events of the revolution in late December 1989, the trial of Ceausescu, and execution of Ceausescu

did.unittitle: Lenin Statue/Ted Koppel Stand-Up/Camcorder Beauty-Roll (69) (Rupen No. B7)
did.abstract: At dusk, crowd watches from square as workers continue removal of Lenin statue. Koppel sitting at base of statue writing in notebook. Koppel stand-up from base of Lenin statue (multiple takes). Panorama of crowd showing photographers and news media in crowd. After dark, workers continue with jackhammer at base of statue
Daytime view of Lenin statue. Long-shot down boulevard to statue in square. Crowd watches from square as demolition work continues. Statue in square at dusk. Statue in square after dark

did.unittitle: Lenin Statue/Daytime Beauty-Roll Part 1/Interviews With Builders (71) (Rupen No. B8)
did.abstract: Lenin statue in Bucharest. Daytime. Demolition work at base of statue. In the square, Koppel interviews a group of men including the builders of the statue about the technical difficulties in removing the statue, and whether or not the statue should be preserved as history/art or destroyed [Romanian with English translations]

did.unittitle: Lenin Statue/Daytime Beauty-Roll Part 2 (72) (Ron No. B8)
did.abstract: Lenin statue in Bucharest. Daytime. Traffic circulating around square. Demolition work at base of statue. Man hands sign around the neck of the statue. Crowd watching from the square. Crane operator securing cables at Lenin's head

did.unittitle: Lenin Statue/Interview with Builders/Interview with Mayor of Bucharest/General Nicolae Cerbu Making Statement at Listening Post. (73) (Rupen No. B9)
did.abstract: Lenin statue in Bucharest. Daytime. In square, Koppel interviews newly appointed mayor of Bucharest regarding the decision and the logistics involved in removing the statue. Koppel interview with unidentified man. General Cerbu makes a statement at telecommunications listening post, explaining the function of the listening post and describing the scope of its focus on monitoring military and diplomatic communications.
Daytime. Crane operator securing cables at Lenin's head. Crowd watches demolition work from the square. Military officers survey the scene. After dark, welders working at the base of the statue

did.unittitle: Major General Nicolae Cerbu Interview Part 1/Securitate Listening Post (75) (Rupen No. B10)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interview with Major General Nicolae Cerbu inside Securitate telecommunications listening center [Romanian with Engish translation] General Cerbu demonstrates the listening equipment and describes how the technical operation works. Cerbu describes the disabling of the listening apparatus and answers questions about the future of government surveillance in Romania. Video includes exterior b-roll footage of listening center
Daytime. Workers at base of Lenin statue. View of pedestrians in square. Crane lifts Lenin statue from podium as crowd cheers. Statue is lowered onto flatbed truck for removal

did.unittitle: Major General Nicolae Cerbu Part 2/Securitate Listening Post (77) (Rupen No. B11)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interview with Major General Nicolae Cerbu inside Securitate telecommunications listening center [Romanian with Engish translation] Cerbu answers questions about the extent and quality of electronic surveillance in Romania under Ceausescu. Video concludes with interior b-roll footage of listening center, including detail views of listening equipment and electronics

did.unittitle: Lenin Statue Driving Away (78) (Ron No. B11)
did.abstract: Daytime. Lenin statue is removed from square on flatbed truck. Crowd in square watches

did.unittitle: Listening Post Stand-Ups/Footage of Exteriors and Interiors at Snagov (79) (Rupen No. B12)
did.abstract: Interior b-roll footage of listening center, including detail views of listening equipment and electronics. Ted Koppel stand-ups inside listening center (multiple takes). Exterior and interior footage of the Snagov presidential palace, including Nicolae Ceausescu's office

did.unittitle: Snagov Interiors/Sergeant Major Enacme Lalescu Interview Part 1 (80) (Rupen No. B13)
did.abstract: Exterior and interior footage of the Snagov presidential palace, including Nicolae Ceausescu's office and living quaraters. Ted Koppel interviews Sergean Major Enacme Lalescu, a military guard at the Snagov palace [Romanian with English translation] Lalescu describes the activities of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu at the palace on the day of their attempted escape (22 Dec 1989)

did.unittitle: Snagov Interiors/Bunker/Sergeant Major Enacme Lalescu Interview Part 2 (81) (Rupen No. B14)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interviews Sergeant Major Enacme Lalescu, a military guard at the Snagov palace [Romanian with English translation] Lalescu describes the activities of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu at the palace on the day of their attempted escape (22 Dec 1989). Interior footage of the Snagov presidential palace, including indoor pool, statue and subterranean bunker

did.unittitle: Colonel Vasile Malutan Interview Part 1 (82) (Rupen No. B15).
did.abstract: Footage of Lenin statue in Bucharest. Ted Koppel interviews Colonel Vasile Malutan, the individual who piloted the helicopter that Nicolae Ceausescu used to flee the Central Committee [in English] Malutan describes the landing, the takeoff, and the events that transpired in the air.

did.unittitle: Colonel Vasile Malutan Interview Part 2 (83) (Rupen No. B16).
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interviews Colonel Vasile Malutan, the individual who piloted the helicopter that Nicolae Ceausescu used to flee the Central Committee Building [in English] Malutan describes the events that happened after Ceausescu departure from Snagov

did.unittitle: Colonel Vasile Malutan Interview Part 3/Walking Shots on Roof/Tunnel Stand-Up (84) (Rupen No. B17)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel interviews Colonel Vasile Malutan, the individual who piloted the helicopter that Nicolae Ceausescu used to flee the Central Committee Building [in English] Malutan discusses his role during the revolution. Footage of cityscape from roof. Walking shots of Koppel and Malutan. Point of view walking shots on roof. Ted Koppel standup inside tunnel system underneath the Central Committee Building.

did.unittitle: Tunnel Stand-Ups/Interview with Army Colonel in Tunnel/Balcony Stand-Ups (85) (Rupen No. B18)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel stand-ups inside tunnel system underneath the Central Committee Building (multiple takes). Interview with Army Colonel in tunnel system [in English] Koppel attempts to extract information about additional levels within the tunnels, but the Colonel denies there existence. Ted Koppel stand-ups on the balcony of the Central Committee Building (multiple takes).

did.unittitle: Ted Koppel Goodnight Stand-Up/Statue of Dr. Petru Groza with Hunger Striking Cleric and Scaffolding/Old and New Poor Housing (86) (Rupen No. B19)
did.abstract: Ted Koppel goodnight stand-up on a sidewalk (multiple takes). Vandalized statue of Dr. Petru Groza with crowds surrounding the monument along with a hunger striking cleric. Scenes of individuals placing scaffolding around the statue. Video ends with various images of poverty ridden neighborhoods and the individuals who live there

did.unittitle: More Poor Housing/Exteriors of House of Republic/Roof Shots of Men Taking Down Flagpole/Roof Shots/Brief Interview with Chief Engineer of House of Republic (87) (Rupen No. B20)
did.abstract: Exterior footage of poor housing in Bucharest. Exterior footage of the House of Republic and surrounding area. Construction workers taking down a flagpole. Rooftop shots of Bucharest. Brief interview with the Chief Engineer involved in building the House of Republic [in English] Interview focuses on the physical characteristics of the building as well as the engineer's insight into its construction
Black and white still photos of individuals and their families. Black and white still photos of Timioara during the Romanian Revolution
Footage of Lenin statue removal operation in Bucharest after the Romanian Revolution of 1989. Associated program: Death of a Dictator

did.unittitle: Audio Casette Transfers Side A (Chanting, Singing) (91)
Koppel Report Open: V/O "Big Daddy" (from Opus) (92)
Original Music: 13 Cues (7:00 approx), 2TRK Stereo Master (94).

did.abstract: Romania December 22 clip reel. Speeches at outdoor rally (night). Footage from inside television station, including statements by Sergiu Nicolaescu and Mircea Dinescu. Speech at outdoor rally (day). Speeches at outdoor rally from top of truck (patriotic music overlay). Major Lupoi statement at television station. Various statements at television station. Large demonstrations in the streets and Revolution Square. Protesters throwing books from balcony of central committee building. Crowds singing and chanting. Statement by Petre Roman [in Romanian]

Romanian television broadcasts. Clip reel includes political statements broadcast on Romanian television; performance of patriotic choral music; CFSN members appeals for a cease fire; scenes of crowds outside television station; statement by Ion Iliescu [in Romanian]
Various statements from Romanian television studio alternate with speeches from balcony [in Romanian] TVR footage

did.unittitle: Clip Reel 4: TVR: Celebrations in Timisoara/Night Rally in Bucharest (CR4) (4c)
did.abstract: Street violence at night. Public demonstrations. Crowds chanting. Various speeches from balcony. Statement by Emil Dumitrescu on Romanian television [in Romanian] TVR footage

did.unittitle: Clip Reel 5: TVR: TV Studio at Night/Demo in Square/Nico Ceaucescu Capture (CR5) (5c)
did.abstract: Various statements from Romanian television studio, including statements read by Teodor Brates, George Marinescu, and others [in Romanian] Night scenes of Bucharest demonstrations. Footage of Nicu Ceausescu capture. TVR footage
TVR broadcast including statement by Ion Iliescu [in Romanian]

Night rally in Bucharest. Daytime fighting. Romanian television broadcast. Dan Marin with bloodied face in studio accused of crimes against Romanian people. Various political statements delivered on Romanian television, including appearences by Ion Iliescu and Petre Roman [Romanian with English translation]

Night fighting. Night rally. Romanian television broadcast. Day fighting. Transport of wounded. Securitate arrested. Ion Iliescu statement on Romanian television. Night fighting with buildings on fire. Various statements broadcast on Romanian television [Romanian with English translation]

Daytime fighting at airport. Bus attacked. Arrests at airport. Daytime celebrations. Romanian television newscast. More airport arrests. Crowd chanting. Airport fighting, tanks, fighter jets. Airport interiors. Interview about fighting at airport and bus attack

Dan Marin on television at airport. Removal of wounded at airport. People watching news on airport television. Fighter jets circle airport, airport fighting. Vehicle inspections, soldiers on patrol in armored vehicles and tanks. Securitate arrests. Bodies pulled from graves. Street fighting. Balcony speeches and crowds chanting. Fighting at airport. Romanian television broadcast showing still photos from the revolution. Street scenes. Cathedral and street memorials

Soldiers cleaning debris from streets. Defaced Ceausescu portrait. Street fighting and buildings on fire. Ceausescu books and pamphlets burned in the streets. Street scenes. Romanian television broadcast

Soldiers patrolling the streets of Bucharest. Scenes of street fighting with soldiers and civilian fighters. Speeches from balcony. Dead Ceausescu. Crowds in Revolution Square. Digging graves and burying the dead. Graveyard memorials and street memorials. Checkpoint searches. Marching crowd and demonstrations

Clips from international news coverage of the Romanian revolution. Crowds in Revolution Square. Street fighting. Soldiers patrolling streets. Street memorials. Dead Ceausescu and Ceausescu trial. Ion Iliescu and Petre Roman press conference. Soldiers outside Romanian television in Bucharest. Clips from Romanian television broadcasts. Scenes inside Interior Ministry facilities. Winter street scenes, tanks in snow. Interview with Corneliu Bogdan [in English] Scenes from inside Ceausescu's Snagov palace. Scenes inside Interior Ministry, including secret files

Clips from international news coverage of the Romanian revolution including interviews and speeches. Crowded Romanian market. Memorial services. Short cartoon of pigs wearing tuxedos. Marching crowds and demonstrations. Footage of fighting in Revolution Square. Pollution from factories. General news coverage including sports, airplane crashes, and fighting near Baku.

File footage of Ceausescu speeches. Footage of pastor Laszlo Tokes and wife Edit Tokes at home and at church in Timisoara. Interview with Laszlo Tokes [in English] Statement by Laszlo Tokes [in Hungarian] Clips from international news coverage of the Romanian revolution including marching crowds and demonstrations. Romanian television broadcasts

did.unittitle: Romanian Revolution Street Fighting/Last Politburo Meeting with Ceausescu (17c)
did.abstract: Civilian demonstrations. Revolutionaries have taken over Romanian T.V. station. Multiple clips of street fighting including tanks and fire fights. Civilians distributing food to soldiers. Hospital footage of individuals injured during the fighting. Last Politburo meeting with Ceausescu

did.unittitle: Nicolae Ceausescu's Last Speech/Petre Interview/Mag Interview (18c).
did.abstract: Clips from Nicolae Ceausescu's last speech at the Palace of the Parliament. Footage of Revolution Square after Ceausescu's speech including his helicopter departure. Interview with a man named Petre [Questions in English, answers in Romanian] Interview pertained to what life was like in Romania 15 years ago and what life was like after the revolution. Interview with a woman named Mag [Questions in English, answers in Romanian] Interview pertaining to what life was like as a woman in Romania, including questions related to contraception

did.unittitle: ABC Bucharest Files/Nicolae Ceausescu's Last Speech (20c)
did.abstract: Footage of bloody individual being led through the streets by a crowd of people. Multiple scenes of street fighting. Nicolae Ceausescu's last speech at the Palace of the Parliament. Footage includes multiple angles of the speech as well as the helicopter departure and the aftermath in Revolution Square

did.unittitle: Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu's Trial/Execution Aftermath (21c).
did.abstract: Nicolae Ceausescu being escorted from a tank. Trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu. Footage and images of the Ceausescus after their execution by firing squad

Press conference regarding the transitional government in Romania [in Romanian and English] Conference addresses the involvement of Communist Party members in the new government as well as issues surrounding free speech. Street memorials. Interior footage of a destroyed building. Multiple scenes of individuals walking the streets of Bucharest. Footage of individuals replacing windows. Armed soldiers searching a building with unarmed civilians. Vehicle check points. TVR broadcast footage. Clip of a black and white movie in English.

did.unittitle: Timosoara Demonstrations/Statements of Individuals that were a Part of the Demonstrations (23c)
did.abstract: Large demonstration in Timosoara. Street memorials. Several individuals making statements into a camera. Dialogue between army officer and civilians. Footage of meeting [in Romanian] Interviews and statements made by a variety of individuals during and after the Timosoara demonstrations. Street fighting (night). Interview with several handcuffed individuals. Street fighting (day). Brief segment from TVR

did.unittitle: Romanian Revolution Demonstrations/Street Fighting/Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu's Trial (24c)
did.abstract: Couple being searched and held at gun point by soldier. Home footage of Romanian streets during the revolution with commentary by the individual operating the camera [in Romanian] Press conference with military officer. Footage of Romanian demonstrations with commentary. TVR footage. Street fighting (night). Burning building. Mass graves. Trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu

did.unittitle: Romanian TV Clip Reel 1: Dub of Clip Reel Compiled by ABC Bucharest (25c)
Romanian TV Clip Reel 4A/Plus Sahia Films Clip Reel (29c)

did.abstract: Black and white footage of an early Nicolae Ceausescu speech. Ceausescu receiving medal in England. Ceausescu meeting with a variety of world leaders including Anwar Sadat, Mikhail Gorbachev, and several Iranian leaders. Journalist segment with interview [in Romanian] Interview with individual explaining why Ceausescu used faked photos in publications

did.unittitle: ABC Buchrest/Filed Cass. Dub from ABC and ITN (32c)

did.abstract: Ceausescu File Footage. Scenes of Ceausescu delivering speeches, meeting with diplomats, and posing for photo ops. Ceausescu meeting with a United States diplomat. Soldiers marching in parade. Footage of empty Romanian grocery stores. Footage of Romanian factories.

Children visiting a Romanian museum filled with Ceausescu propaganda. Footage of Romanian city in rubble. Crowded streets and busses. Factories and heavy industry. Ceausescu File Footage. Scenes of Ceausescu delivering speeches, meeting with diplomats, and posing for photo ops. Ceausescu meeting with Yasser Arafat. Segment about Romania narrated in German

did.unittitle: Zoe Ceaucescu Dragged into TV Station/Timisoara Mass Graves/Crowds in Front of Timosoara Opera House (37c)
did.abstract: Streets of Bucharest after the Revolution. Zoe Ceaucescu being dragged into a TV station. Timisoara mass graves. Graves include images of burned and disfigured bodies. Large crowd assembled in front of Timosoara opera house. A speech is being delivered to the crowd

did.unittitle: Iasi Demonstrations/Books Thrown out of Windows/Dead Bodies on the Street//Nicolae Ceausescu Villa at the Seaside Resort of Neptun (38c).
did.abstract: Demonstrations and crowds marching. Books burning in the street. Books being thrown out of windows. Images of dead bodies. Footage of hospital and injured patients. Exterior footage of Ceausescu's villa in Neptun. Interior footage of Ceausescu's villa in Neptun
Demonstrations and crowds marching. Large crowd assembling outside of a building (multiple angles and vantage points). Street fighting

did.unittitle: ABC Bucharest Tape/Interiors of House of Republic/Interviews with Soldiers/Exteriors of House of Republic (19c)
did.abstract: Press conference in Romanian. Interior footage of the House of the Republic (multiple angles and vantage points). Brief interview with soldier regarding the construction of the House of the Republic. Balcony shots. Brief interview with soldier regarding Ceausescu's use of the House of the Republic as well as the building itself. Exterior footage of the House of the Republic

Footage of the Ceausescus doing a variety of activities with music in the background. Activities include hosting parties, walking in snowy streets, talking with farmers, hunting, boating, receiving awards, playing with children, and greeting enthusiastic citizens. Aerial footage of Romanian countryside. Footage of various bodies of water

Footage of the Ceausescu's doing a variety of activities with music in the background. Activities include hosting parties, hunting, boating, playing with children, and greeting enthusiastic citizens. Ariel footage of Romanian countryside. Footage of various bodies of water
Footage of the Ceausescu's doing a variety of activities with music in the background. Activities include walking, hiking, hunting, and playing with dogs.

Documentary in Czech. Ceausescu delivering speeches, including his last in Bucharest. Choir performing song about Ceausescu. Street fighting. Hospital with patients. Footage of the Ceausescu's trial. Mass graves. Footage of some of the destruction caused by the revolution. Soldiers searching buildings. Scenes of the Ceausescu's execution. Mourning and street memorials

Individual giving a statement in Romanian. War medals. Several scenes from a hospital, including interviews with patients and staff. Handcuffed hospital patients. Caskets. Scenes from a morgue. Interview with soldier in damaged building [in Romanian]

did.unittitle: Interview with Military Officer/Tour of the Tunnels (E)
did.abstract: Interview with military officer regarding the use and implementation of various sound recording devices [in Romanian] Close up of text related to the devices. Soldiers leading a tour of a command center. Close up of a document containing Securitatea information. Interior footage of tunnels. Interview with military officer in the tunnels
Interior footage of unknown building. Soldiers walking through building. Graffiti related to Ceausescu. Footage of jail like cells. Footage of tunnels. Soldiers searching the tunnels
Demonstrations and crowds marching. Large crowd assembling outside of a building (multiple angles and vantage points). Mass graves. Bullet holes in shop windows. Street memorials

did.unittitle: Mircea Dinescu with Crowds/TV Station Rally (K)
did.abstract: Demonstrations and crowds marching. Large crowds assembling. Mircea Dinescu delivering a speech to the assembled crowd [in Romanian] Rally outside TV station. Crowds chanting. Individuals delivering speeches to cheering crowds

Free Romanian Television's (TVRL) first broadcast. Includes speeches from Mircea Dinescu and other prominent revolutionaries. Series of individuals delivering speeches to crowds assembled outside. Demonstrations

Romanian television broadcast containing political statements from several individuals. Night rally. Speeches being delivered to large crowd assembled outside of a building [in Romanian] Demonstrations
Romanian television broadcast. Various political statements delivered on Romanian television. Street fighting. Night rallies. Brief clip of American TV show
Romanian television broadcast, containing political statements from a variety of individuals. Close ups of newspaper articles and photographs. Night rallies and demonstrations
Romanian television broadcast, containing political statements from a variety of individuals and panels
Romanian television broadcast, containing political statements from a variety of individuals and panels

Nicolae Ceausescu departing from Romania. Aerial footage from plane. Ceausescu landing in Iran and being greeted by several people. Ceausescu in a large meeting. Military officers questioning individuals in a courtroom setting

did.unittitle: Romanian Television Broadcast/Ceausescu Speeches/Demonstrations/Military Speech Outside the Palace of Parliament (T) (P246) (201J)
did.abstract: Romanian television broadcast about Ceausescu's trip to Iran. Footage includes Ceausescu leaving Romania, arriving in Iran, and meeting with diplomats. Series of speeches by Ceausescu. Demonstrations and crowds marching. Night rallies. Street fighting. Military officers delivering speeches to crowd gathered outside of the Palace of Parliament

did.unittitle: Demonstrations/Speeches Outside Palace of Parliament/Discourse Inside Palace of Parliament (U) (P247)
did.abstract: Demonstrations. Speeches outside the Palace of Parliament. Footage inside the Palace of Parliament, including dialogue between several individuals. Night rallies. Street fighting. Clips of Stefan Gusa.

did.unittitle: Discourse inside Palace of Parliament/Demonstrations/Street Fighting (V) (P248)
did.abstract: Clips of individuals inside a building while fighting is going on outside. Peopling watching TVR. Night rallies and demonstrations. Footage of several meetings taking place. Phone calls. Street fighting (daytime).

did.unittitle: Vasile Malutan Interview/Interior Footage of Plane/Interior Footage of Helicopter/Hospital and Patients/War Medals (W)
did.abstract: Interview with Vasile Malutan, Ceausescu's pilot. Interior footage of plane [in Romanian] Interior footage of storage compartments next to runway. Interior footage of helicopter. Close up of document. Hospital patients and staff, including dialogue. Individuals wiping feet on Ceausescu poster. Several dead bodies in a morgue. Caskets. Footage of war medals.

did.unittitle: Close Up of Top Secret Document (X)
did.abstract: Close up documents. Multiple pages

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous TV Material (officers talking about Timisoara and General Chitac's role; General Milea's orders on 21-22 Dec) (43C) (44C) (45C)
Timisoara, Bucuresti, Sibiu. Procesul Lui Ceausescu. 1989. (10).

did.abstract: Ted Koppel interview through translator with Romanian Army Major. Army Major discussing topics related to the Romanian Revolution
Street memorials. Demonstrations and crowds marching. Street fighting (day). Street fighting (night). Crowd assembling in front of building
Street fighting (day). Footage of several dead bodies in a morgue with music in the background. Individual discussing and showing the fatal injuries of the casualties in the morgue. Graves

did.unittitle: George H. Bush Visits Romania/August 23 Celebrations/Nicolae Ceausescu Receiving Award (41C)
did.abstract: George H. Bush visiting Romania. Footage includes George and Barbara Bush greeting individuals, eating dinner, and meeting with the Ceausescu's. George Bush delivering a speech [no audio] The Ceausescu's at the August 23 celebration in Romania. Nicolae Ceausescu receiving an award and delivering a speech [no audio]

did.unittitle: Listening Post/Petre Roman Speech/Nicu Ceausescu at the U.N. (42C).
did.abstract: Interior footage of a Romanian listening post. Footage includes individuals giving a tour of the listening post as well as discussing the items within the post. Petre Roman delivering a speech to a crowd [in Romanian] Nicu Ceausescu at the U.N
Romanian newscast. Newscast appears to be related to a story about the military. Military officer addressing the media. Large meeting, made primarily of military personnel
Large meeting, made primarily of military personnel. Romanian newscast. Footage includes a demonstration and a brief interview with a demonstrator
Romanian newscast. Large meeting, made primarily of military personnel.
Large meeting, made primarily of military personnel.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous TV Material Part 5 of 7/Military Panel Part 1 (47C).
did.abstract: Individual discussing and displaying a variety of guns. Military personnel reporting to Stefan Gusa. Gusa and another individual making a series of phone calls. Demonstrations. Interview with unknown individual. Interview with hospital patients. Paul Soloc hosting a panel of three military officers

did.unittitle: The Koppel Report: Death of a Dictator (DW26) (Master)
did.abstract: "Of all the revolutions that swept Eastern Europe late last year, only Romania's led to massive bloodshed. It was the most violent, the most confusing, and the least conclusive of all the uprisings. All of the hatred, the fear, the rebellion was directed at Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, the Romanian dictator and his wife who had ruled this country with an iron fist for a generation. ... And when the hostility finally erupted, the battles were fought in, and under, the streets of Bucharest, exposing a dark world that still haunts the Romanian psyche."

Manea family watching an English television program about communism in Russia. Footage of family drinking tea, talking, and watching TV. Interview with Simona Pavel [in English] Pavel discusses her experience during the December 17th protests in Timisoara, the army shooting into the crowd, the climate of fear created by the Securitatea, and the conditions in Timisoara that allowed for the revolution to happen.
Footage of a rural cemetery. Individuals lighting candles next to graves. Beauty Roll of city streets, civilians, buildings, bridges, and college campus. Footage of a newspaper stand

Interview with Dr. Doros Bordos [in English] Bordos discusses the operations he performed on December 17th. All three doctors interviewing next to one another

did.abstract: Interview with Doreal Ciaca, a truck driver [in Romanian translated into English] Ciaca discusses driving a truck from Timisoara to Bucharest around the time of the revolution. Ciaca was hauling dead bodies, but was unaware of what was in the truck. Footage of buildings and pedestrians in Liberty Square (multiple views). Blind gypsy busking in front of large crowd, singing and playing the accordion.

Interview with Ladislau Revesz [in English] Revesz discusses the shootings in Timisoara, the protesters reactions to the shootings, the conditions in Timisoara that allowed for the revolution to happen, and the current state of Timisoara. Footage of Revesz walking with his significant other

Interview with Victor Popa [in English] Popa is standing in front of a TV explaining what is happening in a video he recorded during the revolution. Videotape contains footage of an army attacking a crowd of people, an ambulance, and demonstrations. Popa continues the interview away from the TV and discusses his experiences during the revolution as well as the conditions in Timisoara that allowed for the revolution to happen

Interview with Victor Popa [in English] Popa discusses the violence he saw from his apartment on December 17th, his speculation as to who was driving the tanks on December 18th, and the sequence of events he captured on his video camera. Popa then discusses the sequence of events he captured on his video camera in Romanian

Ted Koppel and Ladislau Revesz talking at a distance. Interview with Revesz [in English] Revesz discusses the individuals who rallied around Laszlo Tokes's church, the beginnings of the revolution, the climate of fear created by Nicole Ceausescu and the Securitatea, and the current state of Romania

did.unittitle: Ladislau Revesz Interview Part 2/Ted Koppel Walk Around (T-27) (T7 RUP)
did.abstract: Interview with Ladislau Revesz [in English] Revesz discusses speculation surrounding Russia's involvement in the revolution, the protests in Timisoara, the discovery of mass graves, and the current political climate of Romania. Revesz asserts that since the revolution, Romanians have found it increasingly difficult to identify the enemies of Romania and that the country largely questions the legitimacy of its new rulers. Ted Koppel walk around.

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Lionel Chapman; Producers: Kerry Smith Marash, Pat Cook, Jill Fieldstein, Tara Sonenshine; Associate Producers: Peter Demchuk, Deirdre Koppel; Managing Editor: Ted Koppel; Production: Koppel Communications Inc.

This documentary examines the effects of the War on Drugs and drug enforcement policy on the criminal justice system in New York City. Tracking a few representative cases through the criminal justice process, the program looks at the roles of judges, defense attorneys, prosecutors, police and defendants in a system that is strained to the breaking point. The bulk of the program focuses on the narcotics trial of defendant Desmond Legister. Short segments also focus on the work of in-the-field undercover police officers at the Port Authority bus terminal, the workings of "Part N", a special court established to handle the overload of narcotics cases, and a look at the city's Family Court with the views of presiding judge, Judith Sheindlin. This program won a Golden Gavel Award from the American Bar Association in 1990.

The vast majority of the tapes associated with this program are original footage field recordings of court proceedings, police activities, jail procedures and extensive interviews with lawyers, judges, defendants and police. Subjects featured include: Detective Sergeant Richard Canale, Jeremy Schneider, Patrick Joyce, and Marty Murphy of the New York City Legal Aid Society, New York Supreme Court Judge Budd Goodman, Chief Assistant District Attorney Robert Silbering, and New York Family Court Judge Judith Sheindlin (later famous as Television's "Judge Judy"). Approximately 200 of the 408 tapes contain original footage recordings of daily trial proceedings primarily related to 2 cases (multiple cameras over multiple days): the Comacho trial and the Legister trial. The collection contains a batch of police undercover audio tapes, the audibility of which was central to the Legister trial. There is a very small amount of post-production material (mostly graphics and audio tracks) in addition to broadcast masters.

did.unittitle: The Legalization of Drugs/A National Town Meeting: The Legalization of Drugs

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Richard N. Kaplan; Director: Roger Goodman; Production: Koppel Communications Inc., ABC News.

This program is an initial one hour panel-debate ("The Koppel Report: The Legalization of Drugs"), later followed by two hours of town meeting discussion on the topic of drug legalization ("Nightline: A National Town Meeting: The Legalization of Drugs"). Panelists include: Jesse Jackson, Ed Koch, William F. Buckley Jr., Kurt Schmoke, William von Raab, Charles Rangle, Alan Dershowitz and others.

From the program introduction: "It may be the most effective, if least popular solution to our nation's drug problem. It is without question the most controversial. What would happen if we legalized marijuana, cocaine, even heroin? ABC News correspondents, and our affiliates, have been compiling answers to that question for months." This Koppel Report/Nightline town hall meeting features panel discussion with questions from the live audience and via telephone call-in. Short setup pieces cover specific drug use and drug policy issues, including the effectiveness of interdiction/criminalization, cigarettes (nicotine), media/Hollywood representations of drugs and drug use mixed signals).

There is a single Betacam tape labeled "Koppel Report: Drug Legalization", and a 1" C dub of the original master. In addition to these tapes, there are 2 VHS tapes covering the 2 hour Nightline town meeting (labeled: "1st hour" and "2nd hour").

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Richard N. Kaplan; Director: Marvin Schlenker; Editorial Manager: Ted Koppel; Production: Koppel Communications Inc.

Based on the conceit of explaining the world of 1988 to future generations or to life forms on distant planets, this documentary touches on such topics as the natural world, technology, religion, international politics and public health policy. The program features short presentations on a number of topics including Billy Graham on religion, Richard Nixon on US-Soviet relations, Jean-Michel Costeau on the state of the environment, Jane Goodall on endangered species, Jean-Pierre Hocke on the United Nations and the world refugee crisis, Desmond Tutu on racism, Nita Barrow on the state of the developing world, Steve Jobs on computer technology and Stevie Wonder on music.

The majority of the tape holdings for this program are short segment pieces with Richard Nixon, Jean-Michel Cousteau, Desmond Tutu, C. Everett Koop, Nita Barrows, Billy Graham, Carl Sagan, Jane Goodall, Steve Jobs, Stevie Wonder and others. Tapes include original footage versions, masters and protection copies. Approximately 35-40 tapes are post-production materials, and there are several quality dubs of the final program, as well as three broadcast masters.
