scopecontent.p: This documentary examines the dramatic transformations in the Soviet Union through the lens of human sexuality. The program considers a host of issuesabortion, family planning, homosexuality, dating, AIDS, pornography and prostitutionproviding an in-depth view of Soviet society in the midst of the Glasnost era. Interviews include doctors, government officials, sex workers, artists and ordinary citizens.

Much of the material associated with this program is original footage (Jul-Nov 1990) containing: multi-tape interviews with doctors, government officials, ordinary citizens, artists and sex workers; location and b-roll footage related to the many elements explored by the program; hidden camera ("hat cam") footage, etc. Most of the remaining tapes (about 50) are clip reels and dubs from Soviet television and film documentaries. There are about 30 post-production tapes, especially audio voiceovers and translations. There are two broadcast masters, as well as D-2 digital tape copies of the final broadcast version of the show.

did.abstract: Interview with Vladimir Borev, chief editor of independent Russian journal on video culture [Russian with English translation] Borev discusses the negative treatment of video by Soviet Union mass media, the difference between erotica and pornography, the impact of films like "Little Vera" on Russian culture, the video black market, and sexuality in the Soviet Union

did.unittitle: Video Journal Beauty Roll/Video Checkout Window/Erotic Paintings In Gallery (Sex 2)
did.abstract: Interior footage of video journal office. Vladimar Borev working with magazine layout. Woman sitting at a table handing out literature to a series of individuals (outside). Video checkout window with customer. Footage of erotic paintings in a gallery

did.unittitle: AIDS Clinic Beauty Roll/Dr. Pokrovsky Interview Part 1 (Sex 3).
did.abstract: Footage of a rural town shot from a moving vehicle. Interior footage of a Soviet Union AIDS clinic with scenes of individuals working in a lab. Interview with Dr. Pokrovsky [in English] Pokrovsky discusses the Soviet Union's response to AIDS, the causes of AIDS in the Soviet Union, and the consequences of anti-homosexual legislation and AIDS education

did.unittitle: Dr. Pokrovsky Interview Part 2/Vladimir Krasickov Interview Part 1 (Sex 4)
did.abstract: Interview with Dr. Pokrovsky [in English] Pokrovsky discusses sexual revolution in the Soviet Union, STDs, and the relationship between the Russian economy and AIDS. Interview with AIDS patient Vladimir Krasickov [in English] Krasickov discusses the Soviet Unions rejection of AIDS, sexual revolution, and homosexuality in Soviet Russia
Individuals holding signs and protesting outside of a building. Condoms laying in a puddle. Footage of individuals looking at art in an exhibition hall. Glazunov paintings. Close-ups of paintings

Interview with Film Director Peter Todorovsky [Russian with English translation] Todorovsky discusses prostitution in the Soviet Union, reactions to his films, and the symbolism of specific movie scenes

did.unittitle: Peter Todorovsky Interview Part 2/Boris Kuznetsov Interview (Sex 8).
did.abstract: Interview with Film Director Peter Todorovsky [Russian with English translation] Todorovsky discusses prostitution in the Soviet Union, the symbolism of specific movie scenes, and the future of the Soviet Union. Interview with Film Director Boris Kuznetsov [Russian with English translation] Kuznetsov discusses the freedom of the body and mind, the sexual revolution, and the symbolism of his films

Footage of a Russian city shot from a moving vehicle. Interview with Larissa Remennick [in English] Remennick discusses issues facing Soviet women, maternity clinics, abortions, sex, and the general condition of women in the Soviet Union

Interview with Larissa Remennick [in English] Remennick discusses issues facing Soviet women, prostitution, the sexual revolution, and the general condition of women in the Soviet Union. Remennick suggests that the sexual revolution has largely stemmed from the country's younger populations

Interview with Dr. Oleg Nikolayev, a prostitution expert [Russian with English translation] Oleg discusses some of the problems prostitutes face, his relationship with the prostitution community, AIDS, sexual revolution, and the culture of prostitution in the Soviet Union. Nikolayev's biggest concern about prostitution in the Soviet Union is the spread of AIDS and other venereal diseases

Footage of several Soviet weddings. Interview with a bride and groom [Russian with English translation] Bride and groom discuss their future plans and how they intend to live with the groom's parents after the ceremony. Footage of several wedding parties and people dancing. Crowds gathering in the halls of the building where the weddings are taking place
Footage of several Soviet weddings, including scenes of a specific couples ceremony. Wedding parties watching video of their ceremonies, taking pictures, and drinking

Interior footage of Nina's apartment. Footage includes scenes of the kitchen and Nina cooking. Interview with Nina [Russian with English translation] Nina discusses the difficulty of purchasing goods in the Soviet Union, abortion, contraception, home life, and privacy

Interview with Nina [Russian with English translation] Nina discusses bureaucracy in the Soviet Union, corruption, prostitution, and personally being accused of prostitution by the government. Nina goes on to discuss how women are treated by men in the Soviet Union, the institution of marriage, unhappiness in the country, and younger generations lack of morals and goals

Interview with Nina [Russian with English translation] Nina discusses several women's issues including contraception, abortion, abortion laws, hospital conditions for women, and the general condition of women living in the Soviet Union

Interview with Julia, Nina's daughter [Russian with English translation] Julia discusses topics related to what life is like for young people in the Soviet Union. Topics of discussion include, what she does for fun, what she talks about with her friends, dating, sex, marriage, youth prostitution, drug use, religion, and Western influence on popular culture

did.unittitle: Julia Interview Part 2/Driving With Nina Part 1 (Sex 18)
did.abstract: Interview with Julia, Nina's daughter [Russian with English translation] Julia discusses topics related to what life is like for young people in the Soviet Union. Topics of discussion include religion, fashion, and her feelings about her parents divorce. Nina driving through a Soviet town. Footage includes interior and exterior shots of the vehicle as well as footage of the surrounding area

did.unittitle: POV Shots In Nina's Car/Driving With Nina Part 2 (Sex 19)
did.abstract: Point of view footage from Nina's car. Camera captures everything in front of the moving vehicle. Driving in traffic. Scenes of Nina driving

Footage of a carnival located next to a river. Individual selling a newspaper with a naked woman on the front page. Outdoor concert. Scenes of couples holding one another while watching the concert. Footage of carnival rides including footage taken from the top of the Ferris wheel

did.unittitle: Ismailova Park Beauty Roll/Katya Interview Part 1 (Sex 21).
did.abstract: Scenes from Ismailova Park. Footage includes individuals selling exotic art, crafts, and a variety of other material goods. Individuals walking through the park. Interview with Katya [Russian with English translation] Katya discusses what life is like for a young woman living in the Soviet Union. Topics include nightlife, western exposure, sexual revolution, where young people have sex, prostitution, and modeling.

did.unittitle: Katya interview Part 2/Beauty Roll Moscow University/Svetlana Vickers Interview Part 1 (Sex 22)
did.abstract: Interview with Katya [Russian with English translation] Katya discusses the emergence of modeling in Soviet Russia, the treatment of women by men, and some of her ideological beliefs. Walking shots of Katya at Moscow University. Interview with Svetlana Vickers [Russian with English translation] Vickers discusses how the Soviet Union polices morality, an erotic art exhibit, and sex in Soviet Russia

did.unittitle: Svetlana Vickers Interview Part 2/Katya Vickers interview (Sex 23).
did.abstract: Interview with Svetlana Vickers [Russian with English translation] S. Vickers discusses sexuality in the Soviet Union, pornography, ideological beliefs, and the treatment of women by men. Interview with Katya Vickers [Russian with English translation] K. Vickers discusses the communist youth league, where young people have sex, contraception, abortion, prostitution, and femininity.

did.unittitle: Paulik Statue/Party Beauty Roll/Party Interviews Part 1 (Sex 24).
did.abstract: Paulik figurine. Footage of young people at a party. Footage includes individuals smoking, drinking, conversing, listening to music, and dancing. Interview with individuals at party [primarily in Russian with some English] Individuals discuss sexuality in the Soviet Union, pornography, and the sexual revolution.

Interviews with individuals at party [primarily in Russian with some English] Individuals discuss sex in the Soviet Union and related topics. Interview includes footage of a divorced couple talking about marriage in Soviet Russia
Footage of Larissa Remennick playing with her child at park and shopping at a drug store. Footage includes images of surrounding area and scenes from inside the drug store

Interview with Eugenia Debryanskaya, member of the radical party [Russian with English translation] Debryanskaya discusses sexual aspects of the party's platform, the formation of the party, the sexual minority, AIDS, the persecution of homosexuals, sexuality, and politics in the Soviet Union.

did.unittitle: Beer Hall Beauty Roll/Beer Hall Interview (Sex 29)
did.abstract: Interior footage of a beer hall. Footage includes scenes of live music, drinking, smoking, eating, and people conversing. Interview with group of individuals at the beer hall [Russian with English translation] Individuals discuss dating, sex, pornography, and morality. Couple at the table talks about not wanting to marry despite being together for two years and the issues associated with having children in the Soviet Union
Interior footage of a train station in Kiev. Footage includes scenes of people waiting, an individual selling erotica, and people walking

did.unittitle: Exterior Footage of Building/Piquant Show's Joy of Eros Rehearsals (Sex 31)
did.abstract: Exterior footage of buildings from a high vantage point at sundown. Footage of cast before rehearsal. Rehearsal of Joy of Eros, including scenes of topless dancers

Group interview with the Director, Choreographer, and dancers of the Joy of Eros [Russian with English translation] Piquant Show troupe. Troupe discusses the dance company, the meaning of the pieces rehearsed, sex in the Soviet Union, the differences between art and pornography, their feelings about performing in the nude, and sexual revolution

did.unittitle: Joy of Eros Rehearsal/Exterior Footage of the Pravda Cultural Center/Metal Corrosion Beauty Roll (Sex 33)
did.abstract: Dancers rehearsing the Joy of Eros. Exterior footage of the Pravda Cultural Center. Scenes of individuals drinking and smoking in a room. Footage of a band, Metal Corrosion, practicing. Group of females in lingerie enter room and start drinking, striping, and dancing to the band

Scenes of individuals drinking, smoking, and partying. Interview with Metal Corrosion band members with topless women in the background [Russian with English translation] Band members discuss the formation of Metal Corrosion, the use of erotic elements in their performances, and their political ideology
Hidden camera footage of a Russian hotel. Camera crew appears to be capturing footage of individuals picking up prostitutes

did.unittitle: Birthing and Abortion Hospital Part 1/Hospital Interview (Sex 37).
did.abstract: Interior footage of a birthing and abortion hospital. Scenes of nurses conducting a meeting. Footage of a woman giving birth. Interview with a women inside the hospital [in Russian with some English] Footage of an abortion

did.unittitle: Doctor Interview/Maternity Ward Interview/Birthing and Abortion Hospital Part 2 (Sex 38)
did.abstract: Interview with a doctor inside a maternity hospital [Russian with English translation] Doctor discusses surgical abortions, the use of anesthesia, the economic condition of maternity hospitals, and the progress of Soviet hospitals during his career. Interview with woman in maternity ward [Russian with English translation] Woman discusses giving birth, the absence of her husband while giving birth, and abortions in the Soviet Union. Footage of newborns.

Footage of individuals at the beach. Interview with photographer Sasha Borodulin [in English] Borodulin discusses the controversy of Playboy in the Soviet Union, the use of political symbols in his photography, the sexual revolution, privacy, and morality in the Soviet Union

did.unittitle: Sasha Borodulin Interview Part 2/Photo Shoot Beauty Roll (Sex 40).
did.abstract: Interview with photographer Sasha Borodulin [in English] Borodulin briefly discusses the history of sex in the Soviet Union, how younger generations view sex, and his experiences working with Playboy. Beauty roll of Borodulin photo shoot.

Interview with Dr. Igor Kon [in English and Russian with English translation] Kon discusses the sexual history of Russia, Vladimir Lenin's perceptions of sexuality, the relationship between political repression and sexual repression, the state's control on sexual culture, and the lack of sex education in the Soviet Union

Interview with Dr. Igor Kon [in English and Russian with English translation] Kon discusses the general understanding of sexology in the Soviet Union, Playboy, the film "Little Vera," homosexuality, laws pertaining to homosexuality, privacy, and the culture of sexuality in the Soviet Union.

Interview with Dr. Igor Kon [in English and Russian with English translation] Kon discusses the conservative strategy for demonizing sexual liberation, marital rape, sexual subcultures, sex education, sexual revolution, and the moral panic that is taking place in Soviet society.

Interview with Andrei Shipilov, the Director of Gosteleradio Youth Department [in English] Shipilov discusses topics related to sex in the Soviet Union, the relationship between politics and sex, the country's lack of condoms, sex education, and guidelines for displaying appropriate content on Soviet television. Footage of Shipilov standing and watching a Soviet television program

Interview with Juvan Shaestalov, Secretary of Leningrad Writers Union [Russian with English translation] Shaestalov, a conservative poet, discusses the impact of the 1917 Revolution, the breakdown of traditional values in the Soviet Union, sexual revolution, Glasnost, and the influence of western culture on Soviet morality

Interview with Juvan Shaestalov, Secretary of Leningrad Writers Union [Russian with English translation] Shaestalov, a conservative poet, discusses his opinion on Mikhail Gorbachev, Glasnost, the difference between traditional literature and modern eroticism, the Soviet edition of Playboy, and the influence of western culture on the sexualization of the Soviet Union

did.unittitle: Juvan Shaestalov Poem/Juvan Shaestalov Set Up Shots/Sergei Golog Interview Part 1 (Sex 47)
did.abstract: Juvan Shaestalov reciting a poem [Russian with Engilsh translation] Set up shots of Shaestalov. Footage includes Shaestalov working at a desk in his apartment, walking through a courtyard, and entering a building. Interview with Sergei Golog, a Leningrad prostitution researcher [Russian with English translation] Golog discusses a variety of topics related to prostitution in the Soviet Union. Topics include the number of prostitutes in the Soviet Union, the government's definition of prostitution, and the different types of prostitution.

did.unittitle: Sergei Golog Interview Part 2/Sergei Golog Set Up Shots/Preacher at Kazan Cathedral with Christian Singers Part 1 (Sex 48)
did.abstract: Interview with Sergei Golog, a Leningrad prostitution researcher [Russian with English translation] Golog discusses the differences between erotic films and sexual films, the average age of prostitutes, sexuality in the Soviet Union, and the Soviet edition of Playboy. Set up shots of Golog. Footage includes Shaestalov working in an office and walking through the streets. Drunk couple kissing in the street. Individual preaching to a crowd of people in front of the Kazan Cathedral. Christian singers

did.unittitle: Preacher at Kazan Cathedral with Christian Singers Part 2/Prostitutes Outside Leningrad Hotel/Dimitri Shalin Interview Part 1 (Sex 49)
did.abstract: Individual preaching to a crowd of people in front of the Kazan Cathedral. Christian singers. Individual playing guitar and singing with friends next to the preacher. Footage of prostitutes outside a Leningrad hotel. Interview with Dimitri Shalin [in English] Shalin discusses sex in the Soviet Union, the relationship between sex and politics, abortion, contraception, prostitution, privacy, and the sexual revolution

did.unittitle: Dimitri Shalin interview Part 2/Dimitri Shalin Set Up Shots/Park Beauty Roll/Erotic Posters (Sex 50)
did.abstract: Interview with Dimitri Shalin [in English] Shalin discusses sex and politics, glasnost, homosexuality, sex education, contraception, and his current role in helping establish sex education centers in the Soviet Union. Set up shots of Shalin walking through a park (multiple takes). Park Beauty Roll, includes footage of sculptures, foliage, and people walking. Footage of erotic posters on a busy Leningrad street

Interview with gay artist Georgiy Gurianov [Russian with English translation] Gurianov discusses life as a gay artist in the Soviet Union, the acceptance of homosexuality in Leningrad, and art in the Soviet Union. Footage of Gurianov painting in his studio

Interview with gay artist Timur Novikov [Russian with English translation] Novikov discusses life as a gay artist in the Soviet Union, the sexual revolution in relation to art and culture, AIDS, glasnost, and morality in the Soviet Union

did.unittitle: Timur Novikov Set Up Shots/Fortress Beach/Drunk Couple in Park (Sex 53)
did.abstract: Set up shots of Timur Navikov. Footage includes Navikov walking through his studio, entering a "boys club," and walking across a bridge (multiple takes). Beauty roll of young people at Fortress Beach in Leningrad. Footage includes shots of the water, the surrounding area, couples laying out, and people playing volleyball. Beauty roll of drunk couple in the park. Footage includes scenes of the couple stumbling, holding hands, walking, and shots of the surrounding area.

did.unittitle: Gay Men in Catherine Gardens/Gay Men Meeting in Front of a Department Store (Sex 54)
did.abstract: Beauty roll of Catherine Gardens, Leningrad. Footage includes people playing chess, individuals walking, and gay men hanging out on park benches. Footage of gay men meeting in front of an old department store

did.unittitle: Individual Selling Erotic Newspapers/Katya Burova Interview Part 1 (Sex 55)
did.abstract: Footage of individual selling erotic newspapers. Individual making a speech to an assembled crowd [in Russian] Footage of a cafeteria. Ted Koppel interviews Katya Burova in Gorky Park [Russian with English translation] Burova discusses Gorky Park, contraception, abortion, the treatment of abortion patients, morality, and where young people have sex

Ted Koppel interviews Katya Burova in Gorky Park [Russian with English translation] Burova discusses privacy, marriage and divorce, morality in the Soviet Union, and sexuality. Footage of Koppel and Burova talking after the interview
Beauty roll of Gorky Park. Footage includes scenes of couples paddle boating and a Soviet disco. Young people dancing to American music. Katya Burova dancing with a friend.

Ted Koppel interviews Nina Kirillova during lunch [Russian with English translation] Koppel, Kirillova, and crew eating lunch at Kirillova's apartment. Kirillova discusses life in the Soviet Union, the cost of living, her income, government corruption, and why taxi drivers make more money than government workers

Ted Koppel interviews Nina Kirillova [Russian with English translation] Kirillova discusses Soviet politics, the possibility of change in the Soviet Union, the basis for Soviet morality, dissent against the government, glasnost, and the KGB

Ted Koppel interviews Nina Kirillova [Russian with English translation] Kirillova discusses marrying her husband for protection, divorce, alcoholism in the Soviet Union, the treatment of women by men, love and sex, privacy, and contraception.

did.unittitle: Julia Kirillova Interview/Ted Koppel Bathroom Stand Up (Sex 61).
did.abstract: Ted Koppel talking with Nina Kirillova in kitchen [in German] Footage of Kirillova's kitchen. Ted Koppel interviews Julia Kirillova, the daughter of Nina Kirillova [Russian with English translation] J. Kirillova discusses the lack of sex education in school and her knowledge of contraception. Ted Koppel stand up in Nina Kirillova's bathroom (multiple takes). Stand up discusses the living arrangements of divorced couples in the Soviet Union

Ted Koppel interviews Metal Corrosion member Sergei Trotsky [Russian with English translation] Trotsky discusses the formation of Metal Corrosion, the band's political message, AIDS, the lack of condoms, the rational behind nudity in their performances, and sex in the Soviet Union

Ted Koppel interviews Metal Corrosion member Sergei Trotsky [Russian with English translation] Trotsky and Metal Corrosion members discuss morality, lyrics, the success of their band, and being arrested during one of their performances

did.unittitle: Metal Corrosion and their Entourage/Madam Interview Part 1 (Sex 64).
did.abstract: Footage of Metal Corrosion and their entourage smoking, drinking, and hanging out inside their practice space. Exterior footage of Metal Corrosion's practice space. Ted Koppel interviews a Soviet Madam [Russian with English translation] The Madam discusses the differences between western prostitution and Soviet prostitution, the use of alcohol by prostitutes, hard currency prostitution, hostesses, and the rationale behind women getting involved in prostitution

Ted Koppel interviews a Soviet Madam [Russian with English translation] The Madam discusses how she finds and controls her prostitutes, the business side of prostitution, the level of sex education prostitutes have, contraception, the film "Little Vera," and homosexuality

Ted Koppel interviews a Soviet Madam [Russian with English translation] The Madam discusses how she got involved in prostitution, her current role in prostitution, hostesses, and morality in the Soviet Union

did.unittitle: Mezh Hotel Bribe with Tamara/Sasha Borodulin in Restaurant (Sex 67).

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Phyllis McGrady; Senior Producer: Lionel Chapman; Segment Producers: Susan Mercandetti, Jeff Milstein, Kathleen Pearce, Marianne Keeley, Tara Sonenshine; Field Producers: Marianne Keeley, Tara Sonenshine, Rupin Vosigimorukian; Production: Koppel Communications Inc.

This documentary explores in-depth the international democratization of television media and message control brought on by the wide spread availability of camcorders, VCRs and other media technologies. Topics analyzed include Nicaraguan president Daniel Ortega's video conferencing outreach efforts; the importance of television and video to the revolutions in Eastern Europe, particularly the Solidarity movement in Poland; the influence on world opinion of first-hand documentation of the Palestinian experience during the First Intifada; the evolution of Soviet television and public relations during the Gorbachev/Glasnost era; the extent and limits of government television propoganda efforts like those carried out by the US Information Agency and it's international Worldnet television service.

There are around 90 tapes of dubs and clips from international television broadcasts, including World Net programming; US TV shows like Dallas, Cosby and The Price is Right; examples of Soviet television programming; broadcast news footage of events in Poland (Solidarity movement) and the Middle East (Palestine). The majority of the holdings (160 tapes) consists of: original footage interviews, b-roll and field footage including interviews with Lawrence Eagleburger, Richard Holbrook, General Secord, Ted Turner, Roger Ailes and many others; footage and interviews related to USIA/World Net operations; many hours of footage of interviews on Soviet television, including a many part interview with Vladimir Posner; original footage and interviews related to Poland and the Middle East. A substantial number of tapes (approximately 45) are post-production materials, mostly bump-ups and clip reels compiled from the clip tapes, but also including audio masters, graphics and edit masters of the final segments. There are 2 broadcast masters of the final program.

did.abstract: Interview with politician Pat Buchanan [in English] Buchanan discusses the White House use of television, the United States Information Agency, the Soviet Union, and television as a weapon

Interview with politician Pat Buchanan [in English] Buchanan discusses Ted Turner, CNN, Iran, television as a weapon, the mass media, television as a medium for distributing information, the use of television during the Beijing Spring, and the Soviet Union.
Interview with politician Pat Buchanan [in English] Buchanan discusses the United States position in the ideological war being waged through television, CNN, and the United States Information Agency

did.unittitle: Russian Cemetery in St. Genevieve des Bois (FTV-090)
did.abstract: Footage of television crew for the Polish group Video Kontakt shooting in the cemetery at St. Genevieve des Bois. Footage includes two men talking on a bench, shots of the camera crew working, the cemetery, and a priest making a statement [in Russian]

did.unittitle: Kontakt in the Studio/Kashnia Interview Part 1 (FTV-091)
did.abstract: Footage of individuals working in Video Kontakt studio. Interview with Kashnia, a member of Video Kontakt [in English] Kashnia discusses the purpose of Video Kontakt, smuggling videos into European countries, camcorders, and Video Kontakt's relationship with Solidarity

Interview with Kashnia, a member of Video Kontakt [in English] Kashnia discusses the number of camcorders in Poland, the impact of video in Poland, state run television, and the rationale behind basing Video Kontakt out of Paris

Series of video clips taken from World Net's "Dialogue." Footage includes brief interviews with Vice President Dan Quayle, Jeane Kirkpatrick, Astronaut Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin, Mayor Andrew Young, William Reilly, and Karlyn Keene. Interviewees discuss topics related to foreign policy, domestic policy, the environment, and women.

Interview with Carnegie Institute member Andrew Nagorski [in English] Nagorski discusses the role of camcorders in challenging state run media outlets in European countries, the impact of VCRs, parallel culture, and the role of television in Poland. Nagorski also discusses information policy in Eastern Bloc countries, the emergence of an underground video market, Solidarity, and state run media outlets

Interview with Carnegie Institute member Andrew Nagorski [in English] Nagorski discusses topics related to the impact of television on eastern European countries, Solidarity, satellite transmission, state run media in eastern Europe, Mikhail Gorbachev's use of television, and glasnost

Interview with Carnegie Institute member Andrew Nagorski [in English] Nagorski discusses China's use of television as a means of state control, George Orwell, and the lack of a concerted information policy in regards to television in the United States

Interview with Everette Dennis [in English] Dennis discusses the positive and negative aspects of increased camcorder use, how civilian camera footage is used when it reaches a news outlet, the role of journalism in different countries, and the electronic dark room

Interview with Everette Dennis [in English] Dennis discusses some of the negative aspects associated with camcorder use in oppressive governments, the role of television on the West Bank, freedom of the press, and the impact of mass communication on political entities

Interview with Everette Dennis [in English] Dennis discusses Mikhail Gorbachev's use of television in the Soviet Union, freedom of the press, the USIA, and the impact of television on popular culture.

Interview with Major General Richard Secord [in English] Secord discusses the United States broadcasting messages abroad; specifically in Iran, the USIA, propaganda, Iranian communication capabilities, and the overall objective of transmitting pro-American messages in Iran

Interview with Ben Wattenberg, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute [in English] Wattenberg discusses the dissemination of American culture abroad, the USIA, propaganda, the future role of television, Ted Turner, and the power of communication and technology

Interview with Ben Wattenberg, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute [in English] Wattenberg discusses public diplomacy, the use of technology in global politics, television as a tool of democracy, Mikhail Gorbachev's use of television in the Soviet Union, Iran, and the role of television and television consultants in modern elections.

Scenes from a World Net control room. Interview with Chris Snow, Director of the Office of North African, Near Eastern, and South Asian Affairs at the United States Information Agency [in English] Snow discusses the messages that the USIA is sending to the regions he is responsible for, transmitting information in closed governments, public diplomacy, and television as a tool of democracy

Interview with Chris Snow, Director of the Office of North African, Near Eastern, and South Asian Affairs at the United States Information Agency [in English] Snow discusses the challenge of combining the expertise of the USIA with the production capabilities of the television industry, Iran, and competing for viewers attention

Footage of a World Net Drug Broadcast. Footage contains a translated question from General Juan Zarate, Director of the Peruvian National Police Drug Control Office. Zarate asks a World Net commentator about the participation of countries in developing a comprehensive strategy. IDEC with Aldin. USIA

Interview with Grzegorz Boguta, the Executive Editor of Nova Publishing House [in Polish]

A Town Meeting with Nelson Mandela

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Dorrance Smith; Director: Roger Goodman; Production: Koppel Communications Inc., ABC News.

Ted Koppel anchors with guests Nelson Mandela, Rev. Calvin Butts, Gloria Toote, Koos van der Merwe (via taped statement), and others. Two-part broadcast began with one hour at 10:00 PM EST (The Koppel Report) and a follow-up Nightline hour in the usual time slot.

From the program introduction: "And now, Thursday, June 21st, Nelson Mandela comes to Harlem. Seven years ago, while he was still in prison in South Africa, Mandela was awarded an honorary doctorate in absentia at this University. Today, he comes to City College of New York in person, to participate in a town meeting." This joint Koppel Report/Nightline town meeting with Nelson Mandela includes questions from moderator Ted Koppel and from the live audience touching on such topics as: racism; apartheid; US South African policy and sanctions; South African politics and economic development; the South African democracy movement; the ANC's association with the PLO, Libya and Cuba; relations between the ANC and other black South African parties.
There is a single 1 inch videotape master for the first hour of the program and a single VHS dub of the follow-up Nightline hour.

did.unittitle: A Town Meeting with Nelson Mandela (Off-air) (MTW-25) [Part 1] [The Koppel Report]
A Town Meeting with Nelson Mandela [Part 2] [Nightline]
Tragedy at Tiananmen: The Untold Story

scopecontent.p: Executive Producer: Dorrance Smith; Producer: Lionel Chapman; Segment Producers: Bob Haberl, Terry Irving, Marianne Keeley, William Moore; Editorial Manager: Ted Koppel; Editorial Producer: Tara Sonenshine; Production: Koppel Communications Inc.

From the program introduction: "Several weeks ago, before the killing and while the student protest movement was at its peak, we dispatched a number of Chinese-speaking specialists, journalists, and academics to come here [Beijing] and piece together the background of the story. Much of what they, and we, have learned has never been reported before. The 'Goddess of Democracy' [statue] for example: if all had gone according to plan, the students would have left Tiananmen days before the shooting began; she would have been their surrogate, their symbol in an empty square. We will tell of a clandestine meeting, in of all places a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant at the edge of Tiananmen, where a demoralized student leader sought help in planning an escape before the massacre. And we'll report on the state secret revealed publicly by the Secretary General of the Chinese Communist Party [Zhao Ziyang] in the presence of the Secretary General of the Soviet Communist Party [Mikhail Gorbachev]; we'll tell you why and how it may have sealed his fate and that of the students in Tiananmen. This is a story about young dreams and old rivalries, of a battle for power that is still underway, of a single chapter in this nation's long history." This program won an Edward R. Murrow Award from the Overseas Press Club and a Silver Baton from the Alfred I. DuPont-Columbia University Awards.

Most of the holdings for this program consist of post-production materials (paint box/graphics, audio mixes and duplicate/safety masters). There are several broadcast masters and multiple copies/duplicates of ITEL/PAL VHS distribution copies.

scopecontent.p: Executive Producers: Bill Lord (1980-1984), Rick Kaplan (1984-1989), Dorrance Smith (1989-1991), Tom Bettag (1991-2005). Managing Editor: Ted Koppel. Production: ABC News.

Begining in November of 1979 as an ABC News special on the Iran hostage crisis, The Iran Crisis: America Held Hostage, the late-night news program had its official launch as Nightline on March 24, 1980 with Ted Koppel as the founding host. Koppel's last program as anchor air November 22, 2005.

See below for an exhaustive list of Nightline episodes aired during Ted Koppel's twenty-five year tenure on the program. The VHS tapes in the collection are off-air dubs and include commercials (most episodes run approximately 30 minutes). Years covered include: 1980, 1981, 1982, 1983, 1984, 1985,1986, 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005.

altformavail.p: Unless otherwise noted, all VHS tapes listed have been transferred to digital formats and have an accompanying digital transcript. Please note that for some episodes in the collection, video is in digital format only (i.e. no tape source), while some episodes are represented by a digital transcript only (i.e. no video content at all). See notes below for more information.

scopecontent.p: Executive producer: Tom Bettag; Production: ABC News.

This short-lived interview program ran for about six months in the time slot after Nightline, during a transitional period in the network's programming schedule. Most episodes of the program centered on profiles and in-depth interviews in informal settings. Interviews normally conducted by Ted Koppel or Chris Bury included a host of interesting names, including humorists David Letterman, Nia Vardalos, Garry Trudeau, Paul Mooney; humanitarian figures Desmond Tutu and Elie Wiesel; and musicians Bruce Springsteen, Ani DiFranco and Steve Earle.
The collection contains 138 VHS tapes of episodes of this program. Some episodes were re-aired. Each tape runs approximately 30 minutes and includes commercials.

did.abstract: Interview with David Letterman including discussion of Letterman's proposed move to the ABC network, his personal approach to comedy, the experience of his by-pass heart surgery and his experience of the 9/11 attacks. Includes commercials

Interview with Bishop Desmond Tutu including discussion of his ongoing battle with prostate cancer, his role in the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission, and his religious beliefs and moral views as a Bishop in the Episcopal Church. Includes commercials

Interview with Bishop Desmond Tutu including extensive discussion of his religious beliefs and moral views as a Bishop in the Episcopal Church. Also includes some discussion of his persecution by the South African apartheid government. Includes commercials

Interview with Northwest Airlines pilot Lyle Prouse includes discussion of his prosecution for piloting a commercial airliner while intoxicated, his experience with alcoholism, his recovery from addiction and return to the cockpit. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-09-21]

Episode on journalist Peter Nicks includes the story of his drug addiction, subsequent conviction for drug dealing, incarceration, recovery, and eventual transformation to professional journalism. Includes commercials

Episode on journalist Peter Nicks includes the story of his drug addiction, subsequent conviction for drug dealing, incarceration, recovery, and eventual transformation to professional journalism. Includes commercials
Episode on golfer Tiger Woods includes the story of his rise to dominance in the sport featuring interviews with Will Smith, Samuel L. Jackson, Jon Stewart and others. Includes commercials

Interview with Malaysian founder of Sisters of Islam Zainah Anwar includes discussion of the 9/11 attacks, the role of non-governmental organizations in the Muslim world (Sisters of Islam), life in Malaysia, the role of women in Islam, and relations between Islam and the West. Includes commercials

Interview with Canadian General Romeo Dallaire includes discussion of his time as commander of a United Nations' peacekeeping force in Rwanda during the Rwandan genocide and how that experience has effected his life. Includes commercials

Interview with television writer and producer Norman Lear includes discussion of Lear's current health and family life, his television career, the social impact of All in the Family and Archie Bunker, the social influence of television generally, and the responsibilities of citizenship and political activism. Includes commercials.

Interview with young cancer survivor Erin Zammett includes the story of Zammett's ongoing battle with leukemia and her efforts to maintain a productive professional life despite her disease. Includes commercials.

Interview with cyclist and cancer survivor Lance Armstrong includes discussion of his cycling career, his battle with testicular cancer, and his long struggle to win the Tour de France. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-08-06]

Interview with musician Bruce Springsteen at his New Jersey home includes discussion of Springsteen's musical career, his formative years in New Jersey, song writing and the creative process, and the longevity of his performing career. Episode also features musical performances by Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band. Includes commercials

Interview with musician Bruce Springsteen at his New Jersey home includes discussion of the recent reforming of the E Street Band, Springsteen's relationship with wife Patti Scialfa and his relationship with the individual members of the E Street Band. Includes interviews with members of the E Street Band and performances by Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band. Includes commercials

Interview with psychiatrist Fred Freese includes discussion of his ongoing struggles with Schizophrenia, innovations in psychiatric medicine and the treatment of mental illness, and public health policy related to the mentally disabled. Includes commercials

Interview with psychiatrist Fred Freese includes discussion of his ongoing struggles with schizophrenia, innovations in psychiatric medicine and the treatment of mental illness, and public health policy related to the mentally disabled. Includes commercials

Interview with Christian novelist Jerry Jenkins includes discussion of his work on the Left Behind series of novels, his belief in the Rapture, the teachings of Tim LaHaye related to belief in the end of the world, and understanding of Christian evangelicalism. Includes commercials
Interview with comedian Paul Mooney includes discussion of race in America, racism, and his long career as a a comedy writer and performer. Includes commercials

Interview with concert pianist John Davis includes discussion Davis' musical-historical project based on the music of slave-musician "Blind Tom" Wiggins. Includes Davis piano performances. Includes commercials
Interview with US Army commander George Geczy includes discussion of his military career, the impending Iraq War and US troop preparedness for that operation. Includes commercials.

Interview with college football coach Tyrone Willingham includes discussion of his coaching career, his role as football coach at the University of Notre Dame, and explores the challenges faced by African American coaches in college football. Includes commercials

Interview with Sociology professor Morrie Schwartz includes discussion of his ongoing struggle with ALS disease, living with a terminal illness and coping with the inevitability of death. Interview rebroadcast from a previous Nightline episode. Includes commercials

Interview with ex-con chess player Eugene Brown includes discussion of his life story, the time he spent in prison, his involvement with the game of chess, and his use of chess as a means of social outreach. Includes commercials.

Interview with novelist Walter Mosley includes discussion of his career as a novelist, African American literature, the craft of writing novels, the process of adapting books for film, and race relations in America. Includes commercials

Episode examines the story of singer songwriter Eva Cassidy including her death from cancer at an early age and her posthumous recording success. Includes excerpts from Eva Cassidy recordings and performances. Includes commercials

Interview with metal worker Michael Flocco includes discussion of Flocco's son Matthew who died in the 9/11 attack on the Pentagon, Flocco's participation in the Pentagon rebuilding effort, and the difficulty in coming to terms with the loss of a son. Includes commercials

Interview with Sociology professor Morrie Schwartz includes discussion of his ongoing struggle with ALS disease, living with a terminal illness and coping with the inevitability of death. Interview rebroadcast from a previous Nightline episode. Includes commercials

Interview with actress and writer Nia Vardalos includes discussion of her career, the making of the hit movie "My Big Fat Greek Wedding", and her life growing up in a Greek immigrant family. Includes commercials

Episode focuses on the animated character Cita from the BET program "Cita's World". Interviews with voice actor Kittie (Kali Troy) and show producer Tracye Kinzer includes discussion of the concepts behind the show, the popularity of the character Cita, hip hop culture and representations of African American culture in the media. Episode also features a demonstration of the motion caption technology used to create the program "Cita's World". Includes commercials
Interview with "Welfare Queen" Dorothy Woods includes discussion of welfare fraud, welfare reform and the challenges of being poor in an affluent culture. Includes commercials.

Episode focuses on the story of the North Platte Canteen in North Platte, Nebraska. During World War II, the canteen served as a respite stop for troops traveling via railroad to and from overseas deployments. Episode features interviews with canteen volunteers and former soldiers who share their personal recollections of the canteen. Includes commercials

Interview with Sociology professor Morrie Schwartz includes discussion of his ongoing struggle with ALS disease, living with a terminal illness and coping with the inevitability of death. Interview rebroadcast from a previous Nightline episode. Includes commercials
Interview with physician Atul Gawande focuses on the issue of medical mistakes, physician error, malpractice and patient safety. Includes commercials

Interview with Joseph Salvati and his wife Marie includes discussion of his wrongful conviction for murder, the role of the FBI in covering-up the actual assailants and Salvati's eventual release and lawsuit against the US government. Includes commercials

Interview with Olympic gymnast Nadia Comaneci includes discussion of her gymnastics career, her historic performance during the 1976 Olympics, her subsequent life and eventual escape from Communist Romania. Includes commercials

Interview with photographer David Snider includes discussion of his experience growing up with blind parents, his career as a photographer and his lifelong mission of capturing the world of the visually impaired (blind) with photography. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-08-10]

Interview with Israeli forensic pathologist Yehuda Hiss includes discussion of his career as head of the National Institute of Forensic Medicine in Israel, the difficulties of investigating the casualties of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, his experience in the aftermath of the Passover bombing in Netanya and the profound challenges of work as a pathologist. Includes commercials

Interview with blind mountain climber Erik Weihenmayer includes discussion of his quest to climb the "seven summits", his experience climbing Mount Everest, and the experience of his life as a blind person. Includes commercials

Interview with AIDS activist Mary Fisher includes discussion of her personal struggles with the AIDS disease and how it has effected her children, her public activism on behalf of AIDS victims, and her historic speech at the Republican National Convention in 1992. Includes commercials

Episode focuses on the story of 9/11 victims the Whittington-Falkenberg family. Interviews with surviving friends and relatives records the impact of the loss of the entire family aboard American Airlines Flight 77 during the 9/11 attack on the Pentagon. Includes commercials

Interview with photographer Joel Meyerowitz focuses on his photographic documentation of the Ground Zero sight in New York and the struggles he's faced in creating an exhaustive archive of the recovery effort at Ground Zero. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Up Close: Brothers: On Holy Ground
did.abstract: Interviews with New York City firefighters and other first responders about their experiences of the 9/11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the subsequent recovery mission at Ground Zero. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-08-17]

Interview with Barry Minkow includes discussion of his financial fraud conviction and his subsequent reinvention as a evangelical preacher and motivational speaker on fraud and business ethics. Includes commercials
Interview with taxi driver and philanthropist Om Dutta Sharma includes discussion of his financial support for the education of young girls in his home country of India. Includes commercials

Interview with singer songwriter Steve Earle includes discussion of his musical career, his long battle with drug and alcohol addiction, his views on art and politics, his opposition to the death penalty and the controversy surrounding his song "John Walker's Blues". Includes musical performances by Steve Earle. Includes commercials

Interview with Nobel prize winner and Israeli diplomat Shimon Peres includes discussions of his career as a statesman, analysis of Israeli and Palestinian politics, terrorism, and the Middle East peace process. Includes commercials

Interview with Egil "Bud" Krogh includes discussion of his position in the Nixon White House, his role in the Watergate scandal and subsequent conviction and imprisonment for that role. Includes commercials

Interview with Egil "Bud" Krogh includes discussion of his position in the Nixon White House, his role in the Watergate scandal, his subsequent conviction and imprisonment for that role, and his current work to make his experiences an example for the importance of integrity and ethics. Includes commercials

Interview with Native American activist Eloise Cobell includes discussion of long standing government mismanagement of the Native American Trust Funds, her class-action lawsuit against the Department of the Interior, the historical mistreatment of native people, and her personal experience growing up on a Blackfeet Indian reservation. Includes commercials. This episode is an updated version of a previous episode broadcast 2002-07-13
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-07-18]

Interview with professor and Iraqi dissident Kanan Makiya includes discussion of the Saddam Hussein regime in Iraq, historical analysis of the regime and how it has projected power, the atrocities committed against the Kurds after the Gulf War, and the importance of Islam-Jewish relations to stability in the Middle East. Includes commercials

Episode features short profiles and interviews with seven recent MacArthur Fellows. Individuals covered include a jazz musician, a choreographer, a seismologist, a computer scientist specializing in robotics, a visual artist, a photojournalist and a documentary film maker. Includes commercials.

Interview with Selma Subasic includes discussion of her experiences in Tuzla during the Bosnian War, her witness of atrocities committed by Serbian forces, her experiences in mixed Bosnian-Serbian theater company and eventual immigration to the United States. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Up Close: Kelley Family (Fragile X Syndrome)
did.abstract: Episode focuses on the Kelley family and their ongoing struggle with the rare genetic defect, Fragile X Syndrome. This episode is a follow-up to an earlier Nightline broadcast. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-07-18]

Interview with Hollywood producer Robert Evans includes discussion of the biographical film "The Kid Stays in the Picture", Evans' long career as an actor and producer, his years as a studio executive at Paramount Studios. Includes commercials

Interview with Hollywood producer Robert Evans includes discussion of the biographical film "The Kid Stays in the Picture", Evans' long career as an actor and producer, his years as a studio executive at Paramount Studios. Includes commercials

Interview with author Salman Rushdie includes discussion of the 9/11 attacks, his views of the United States and American liberties, the ongoing challenges in the Muslim world, the war on terror, and perceptions of America abroad. Includes commercials
Interview with Univision television host Don Francisco includes discussion of his long career in television, the program Sabado Gigante and the future of television. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-08-21]

Interview with journalist and novelist Anna Quindlen includes discussion of her latest novel "Blessings", the personal challenges of balancing work and motherhood, her views of feminism and the challenges facing women in the contemporary world. Includes commercials
Interview with Arab-American advocate Jack Shaheen focuses on the "gross and repeated distortion of Arabs and Muslims in the movies". Includes commercials
Interview with pediatric neurosurgeon Ben Carson includes discussion of his career as a surgeon and his ongoing battle with prostate cancer. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-08-30]

Interview with pediatric neurosurgeon Ben Carson includes discussion of his troubled upbringing in a poor family, the difficulties facing African Americans in the medical profession and his career as a surgeon. Includes commercials

Episode focuses on the story of Elena Leslie, a young woman who was killed in a New Mexico highway accident, and her mother's effort to realize a highway memorial for her daughter. Includes commercials

Interview with author Alexandra Fuller includes discussion of her experience growing up as a farmer's daughter in Zimbabwe (Rhodesia), her analysis of the difficult race relations in Rhodesia and Africa, and her attempt to come to terms with those experiences through the act of writing. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-10-09]

Episode focuses on the career of legendary Baltimore Colts quarterback Johnny Unitas. Includes interviews with former teammates and Baltimore native, filmmaker Barry Levinson, speaking about Unitas' importance not only to the game of football but to the city of Baltimore as well. Includes commercials
Interview with pediatrician and child psychologist Stanley Greenspan includes discussion of child safety in light of random violence and the threat posed by the DC sniper. Includes commercials

Interview with New York Times executive editor Max Frankel includes discussion of journalistic ethics, balancing the requirements of national security with the public's right-to-know, his experience covering the Cuban Missile Crisis, the DC sniper case, the evolution of journalism, and his long career as a reporter and editor at the New York Times. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Up Close: Moscow: Capitol in Crisis
did.abstract: Episode focuses on the Moscow theater hostage crisis. Includes commercials

Interview with former diplomat Joe Wilson includes discussion of his diplomatic role in Iraq at the time of the Gulf War, his experience with Saddam Hussein as US representative in Iraq at that time, and his analysis of the situation prior to the start of the Iraq War. Includes commercials
Interview with Tim Martin includes discussion of his obsession with the Shakespeare tragedy "Hamlet" and his project to self-produce and star in a production of the play. Includes commercials

Interview with actor and filmmaker Tim Blake Nelson includes discussion of his recent film on the Holocaust, "The Grey Zone". Interview includes extensive discussion of the role of the Sonderkommandos in the Nazi camps. Includes commercials

Interview with judge Joe Brown includes discussion of his experiences as an African American at the UCLA law school, his formative judicial career in Memphis and his eventual transition to a television judge. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Up Close: Ron Beckett and Jerry Conlogue
did.abstract: Episode focuses on the secrets of the mummies. Includes interviews with professors Ron Beckett and Jerry Conlogue including discussion of their television show "The Mummy Road Show", and their global studies of mummies and mummification. Includes commercials

Interview with disabled marathoner Chris Moon includes discussion of Moon's experience as a prisoner of the Khmer Rouge, the loss of his legs in a land mine accident, and his subsequent efforts as a marathon runner with prosthetic limbs. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Up Close: Kelly St. John/Wendy Osborn Stories
did.abstract: Episode focuses on the story of the abduction, rape and murder of a fourteen-year old girl named Wendy Osborn. Investigation of the Wendy Osborn case became the basis for reporter and filmmaker Kelly St. John's documentary "Forever Fourteen" in which she tells of her own similar case at the hands of the same perpetrator Raymond Barthlett . Includes commercials

Episode focuses on classic car enthusiast Dan MacArthur and his travels to Havana, Cuba in search of rare and unique automobiles. Episode also examines contemporary life in communist Cuba and MacArthur's political views on the Cuban embargo. Includes commercials.

did.unittitle: Up Close: A Day in the Life of the US Military
did.abstract: Episode focuses on a photojournalism project to document a day in the life of the military in which over 60,000 photos were collected from around the world during a single 24-hour period. Program includes in-depth stories of three of the photojournalists involved in the project documenting a drill-sergeant conducting Army basic training, fighter-pilot training with top-gun Air Force pilots, and a normal workday for Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld. Includes commercials

Interview with playwright David Henry Hwang includes discussion of his prize-winning play "M. Butterfly", his views relating to identity, and his personal experiences as an Asian American writer. Includes commercials

Interview with Vietnam veteran Steven Tice includes discussion of his wounding during the Vietnam War, his subsequent struggles to recover physically and emotionally, and his long time relationship with Lisa Boyce. Includes commercials

Interview with comedian Jon Stewart includes discussion of his formative years as a comedian, his work on 'The Daily Show", his views on the state of the media and television news, and his views on the art of comedy. Includes commercials

Interview with conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim includes discussion of his trip to perform in Ramallah, his conviction that music can have a positive effect on Israeli-Palestinian relations, his breaking of the Israeli taboo against performing the music of Wagner, and his insights on the art of conducting. Includes musical performances by Barenboim. Includes commercials

Interview with singer songwriter Steve Earle includes discussion of the controversy surrounding his song "John Walker's Blues", his views on art and politics, his first play "Karla" based on the story of Karla Faye Tucker, his views on the death penalty, and his most recent album "Jerusalem". Includes musical performances by Steve Earle. Includes commercials
Interview with Ken Starr includes discussion of his formative legal career, his role in the Clinton investigations, how he now assesses that role in retrospect. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-07-12]

Interview with Charles Moose includes discussion of the DC sniper investigation and Moose's role as investigator and official police spokesman for the Montgomery County Department of Police. Includes commercials

Interview with Charles Moose includes discussion of the DC sniper investigation and Moose's role as investigator and official police spokesman for the Montgomery County Department of Police. Includes commercials

This episode, a joint report with the Los Angeles Times, focuses on the foster care system by following three young people for more than a year after they were emancipated from the system. Includes commercials

This episode, a joint report with the Los Angeles Times, focuses on the foster care system by following three young people for more than a year after they were emancipated from the system. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-09-05]

Interview with surgeon Rick Montz includes discussion of his medical career as an Obstetric and Gynecological Oncologist, his experience treating cancer patients, and his insights into treating terminally ill and dying patients. Includes commercials

Interview with British politician Baroness Emma Nicholson includes discussion of human rights in Iraq, the genocide of the Marsh Arabs in Southern Iraq, and the case for the Iraq War and regime change in Iraq. Includes commercials

Interview with author and television cook Julia Child includes discussion of her formative years, her work on the long-running program The French Chef, the evolution of cooking in the contemporary household, and the changes effecting working women in the latter-half of the 20th century. Includes commercials

Interview with innovative teacher Charles Best includes discussion of his career path from the Ivy League to the New York public schools, his efforts to improve the quality of education in New York City, his work with the non profit organization DonorsChoose.org. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-08-22]

Interview with cartoonist Garry Trudeau includes discussion of his formative years, his admiration of editorial cartoonist Herblock, his long career as a cartoonist, his work on the Doonesbury comic strip, his approach to the craft of comic art,and his views on the impact of editorial cartoons. Includes commercials

Interview with cartoonist Garry Trudeau includes discussion of his work on the Doonesbury comic strip, his views on the impact of editorial cartoons, the First Amendment rights of satirists, his satirical depiction of Frank Sinatra and the Bush presidents, and his approach to the craft of comic art. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Up Close: Mary Kay Stratis and Mary Lou Ciulla
did.abstract: "Two women who lost their husbands in that terrorist attack [Pan Am Flight 103 bombing] met soon after the tragedy; they discovered how much they had in common as they tried to piece together the rest of their lives. Now they have discovered they have something to teach. Their students are also women whose husbands were killed in the attack on the World Trace Center, and in helping these widows rebuilt their lives the two teachers have found unexpected meaning in their own suffering." Includes commercials

Interview with professional poker player Annie Duke includes discussion of her Ivy League education, her career as a poker player, and the challenges of balancing career and motherhood. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-08-09]

Interview with singer and guitarist Bonnie Raitt includes discussion of her long career as a blues musician, her latest album "Silver Lining", the intricacies of human relationships, and how her progressive political views effect her music. Includes musical performances. Includes commercials

Interview with primatologist Jane Goodall includes discussion of her formative training with Louis Leakey, her career studying animal behavior and primates in Africa, and her emergence as an activist for animal rights and environmental concerns. Includes commercials

Interview with psychologist Kay Redfield Jamison includes discussion of her career studying and treating manic depression and her own experience of mental illness as a sufferer of manic depression. Includes commercials

Interview with Cuban exile and musician Willy Chirino includes discussion of his career as a singer and performer, his influence on Latin American music, and his experience as a Cuban exile living in the US. Includes musical performances. Includes commercials
Interview with former Los Angeles Chief of Police Daryl Gates includes discussion of his handling of the Rodney King riots in 1992. Includes commercials

Interview with drug offender Marshall Allen includes discussion of his time in prison, his struggles with mental illness and homelessness, and the difficulties he has faced reintegrating with society. Includes commercials

Interview with pediatric oncologist Stewart Goldman includes discussion of his career treating children with cancer and the challenges of handling death and dying of pediatric patients. Includes commercials
Interview with presidential speech writer Michael Gerson includes discussion of his work in the George W. Bush White House. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Up Close: They Might Be Giants
did.abstract: Episode focuses on the work of the musical group They Might Be Giants. Includes musical performances as well as interviews with fans and band members. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-07-31]
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-07-10]
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-07-11]

Interview with Rabbi Brad Hirschfield includes discussion of his experience as a settler in the West Bank of Israel, his views on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and his evolution from strict Orthodox Judaism to his belief in the fundamental imperative of religious tolerance . Includes commercials

Interview with singer-songwriter Ani DiFranco includes discussion of her career as a solo performer, her resistance to the mainstream music industry, and her views on song writing and the creative process. Includes musical performances. Includes commercials
[duplicates episode broadcast 2002-07-27]

Interview with inventor Dean Kamen includes discussion of his career as an engineer and inventor, his invention of the Segway, his development of innovative medical devices, and his views on the evolution of technology . Includes commercials

Interview with feminist Martha Burk includes discussion of her push to have women members admitted to the Augusta National Golf Club, her career as an advocate for the rights of women and as the Chair of the National Council of Women's Organization. Includes commercials
Interview with athlete Stephon Marbury includes discussion of his career as a basketball player in high school, at Georgia Tech University and as a professional in the NBA. Includes commercials

Interview with singer and Broadway performer Barbara Cook includes discussion of her career as a singer, the demands of performing, her recent tour performing the works of Stephen Sondheim, and her personal struggles with alcohol and obesity. includes musical performances. Includes commercials

Interview with cellist Matt Haimovitz includes discussion of his formative years as a child prodigy, the evolution of his career as a musician and his quest to bring classical music to new audiences in new venues. Includes musical performances. Includes commercials

Interview with advocate Adam Pertman includes discussion of his experience as a adoptive parent and his evolution from Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter to full-time advocate for the rights of the adopted. Includes commercials

Interview with media executive Sumner Redstone includes discussion of his experience as a survivor of a serious hotel fire and his subsequent career as one of the most powerful executives in the media industry. Includes commercials

Interview with musician Jimmy Scott includes discussion of his long career as a jazz singer and performer, the uniqueness of his male-soprano voice, and the other musicians who have influenced his singing style. Includes musical performances. Includes commercials
Interview with painter Peter Malkin includes discussion of his role in the capture of Aldolf Eichmann in Argentina in 1960. Includes commercials

Interview with entrepreneur Kaleil Tuzman includes discussion of the failure of his govWorks.com company during the dot com crash, his reflections on the rise and fall of his business career, and the subsequent film documentary "Startup.com". Includes commercials

Interview with feminist Gloria Steinem includes discussion of how she became a feminist and a public activist, the evolution of her relationship with her mother, reflections on her recent marriage, and her assessment of the success of the feminist movement. Includes commercials
Interview with art forger John Myatt includes discussion of his role in the greatest art fraud of the past century. Includes commercials
Episode focuses on the satirical publication "The Onion". Includes video of a writer's meeting and interviews with individual writers and graphics artists. Includes commercials.

Episode focuses on Arya Singh and the genetic disorder Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA). Episode includes interviews with Arya's parents discussing the difficulties of caring for a child with SMA and their efforts to attract attention and funding for treatment of the disease. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Up Close: Best of Up Close
did.abstract: Episode features selected excerpts from previously broadcast Up Close interviews including David Letterman, Desmond Tutu and Bruce Springsteen. Includes commercials.

Interview with Nobel Laureate Eli Wiesel includes discussion of his experience as a Holocaust survivor, his reflections on religious faith, his thoughts on the impending war in Iraq and his evolution as an author and humanitarian. Includes commercials

scopecontent.p: This public affairs program ran periodically in the Nightline time-slot over the years and provided a means for ABC News figures and other prominent members of the media industry to gather and analyze coverage of key events in the news. Typically, the show was formatted as a panel discussion/debate, often with open audience participation. Some of the topics covered include violence in the media, bias in political coverage, press coverage of political scandals and coverage of high-profile criminal trials.
All original videotapes are VHS dubs (most approx. 90 mins.).

altformavail.p: Unless otherwise noted, VHS tapes have been transferred to digital formats and have accompanying digital transcripts.

scopecontent.p: Special programs in the collection includes ABC News specials, documentaries and mini-series; PBS produced documentaries; and several Koppel Communications produced documentaries, news specials and other programs.

did.unittitle: The Best of Nightline with Ted Koppel, 1980-1990 (Cassette No. 1) (RS-25)
did.abstract: This ten-year anniversary show compiles highlights of some of the most memorable moments from the first decade of Nightline and includes interviews with Nightline producers and viewers. Includes commercials.

Program focuses on 200 years of American history and the history of the US Constitution and features historic news clips, movie clips, historical reenactments, and reflections from hosts David Brinkley, Peter Jennings and Ted Koppel. Includes commercials.

Program focuses on 200 years of American history and the history of the US Constitution and features historic news clips, movie clips, historical reenactments, and reflections from hosts David Brinkley, Peter Jennings and Ted Koppel. Includes commercials.

did.unittitle: Bruce Springsteen (Nightline 7/30, Up Close 7/30, Up Close 7/31) (no commercials)
Jennings Koppel Report: Questions of Policy, Questions of War
did.abstract: Special report on US foreign policy in the Persian Gulf region. Report includes focus on the strategic importance of the Strait of Hormuz, Iran's deployment of Chinese-made Silkworm missiles on Qeshm island, US involvement in the ongoing Iran/Iraq conflict, Kuwaiti attempts to solicit the joint involvement of US and Soviet protections for oil tanker traffic in the region, and the possibility for US military involvement in the conflict. Includes commercials

did.unittitle: Morrie: Lessons on Living (dub from master)
did.abstract: From the program introduction: "He was a dying man who made us witness to the last stages of his journey. ... He was original and unpredictable. ... He shared his fears openly. ... And he shared his many lessons. ... Tonight, conversations with Morrie Schwartz: Lessons on Living." Video compiles three previously broadcast programs.

did.unittitle: Nightline in Primetime: Brave New World: 6th Extinction
did.abstract: Part of an eight-part mini-series, this documentary reported by Robert Krulwich focuses on the subject of extinction. The Earth has previously faced five periods of mass extinction: are we headed for a sixth mass extinction? Will humans be part of this extinction? How will the world be effected? Includes a musical performance by They Might Be Giants.

did.unittitle: Nightline in Primetime: Brave New World: Beyond Atoms
did.abstract: Part of an eight-part mini-series, this documentary reported by Robert Krulwich focuses on theoretical physics. Topics examined include string theory, quantum mechanics, general relativity, particle physics and the quest for a unifying theory of the universe. Includes a musical performance by the Emerson String Quartet.

did.unittitle: Nightline in Primetime: Brave New World: Hope: A Case Study
Nightline in Primetime: Brave New World: Looking for Life
did.abstract: Part of an eight-part mini-series, this documentary reported by Robert Krulwich focuses on the emergence of life on Earth and the possibility of extraterrestrial life in our solar system or elsewhere in the universe. Includes a musical performance by They Might Be Giants.

did.unittitle: Nightline in Primetime: Brave New World: Man and Machine
did.abstract: Part of an eight-part mini-series, this documentary reported by Robert Krulwich focuses on human relations to machines and technology. Technologies examined include airplane autopilot systems, medical devices, computer aids to cognition, computer-capture of dance motion, artificial intelligence, robotics and computer generated animation. Includes a musical performance by They Might Be Giants.

did.unittitle: Nightline in Primetime: Brave New World: Why Not Clone a Human?
did.abstract: Part of an eight-part mini-series, this documentary reported by Robert Krulwich focuses on the practical and ethical dimensions of human cloning.

did.unittitle: Nightline in Primetime: Brave New World: Wired for Speed
did.abstract: Part of an eight-part mini-series, this documentary reported by Robert Krulwich focuses on speed and why it is psychologically attractive to humans. The imperative for speed is examined in relation to the telephone, the brain of a short order cook, the television remote, and other labor saving technologies and practices. Also includes a musical performances by They Might Be Giants and David Pleasant.

did.unittitle: Nightline in Primetime: Crime and Punishment, Part 1
did.abstract: Part of a five-part mini-series focusing on Central Prison in Raleigh, North Carolina, this episode includes interviews with inmates at the prison as well the victims connected to the crimes committed by those inmates. The program also examines the effects of imprisonment on those who are imprisoned with in-depth looks at the prison's mental ward and prison work programs.

did.unittitle: Nightline in Primetime: Crime and Punishment, Part 2
did.abstract: Part of a five-part mini-series focusing on Central Prison in Raleigh, North Carolina, this episodes includes Ted Koppel reporting with a handheld video camera from directly inside the prison, including an overnight stay in cell block H. Interviews with inmates concern the quality of life in prison, dealing with prison violence, inmates' reflections on their crimes and their expectations for their lives.

did.unittitle: Nightline: The Clinton Years (5 Part VHS Series) (N010108-01)
did.abstract: Edited videotape compilation collects five Nightline broadcasts (originally aired 1/8/2001-1/12/2001) covering the eight years of the Clinton presidency from the tumultuous campaign of 1992 through the health care reform struggles, the fight for a second term, the Monica Lewinsky affair and subsequent impeachment acquittal, and the Kosovo War. Features interviews with dozens of Clinton administration officials, political advisors and political analysts.

did.unittitle: Primetime: Moment of Crisis: System Failure
did.abstract: From the program introduction: "All disasters, manmade and natural, dictate a certain rhythm and flow: rescue the living, recover the dead, remove the wreckage, and then, somewhere in there, begin to figure out what went wrong. That's what we thought we did after 9/11: studied the failures, fixed the problems, streamlined the system. The lesson of New Orleans is the system is still fatally flawed. ... Tonight, the lessons of Katrina: how and why the system failed." Includes commercials

From the program introduction: "These are personal stories of some of the men and women of ABC News who dug, ducked, ran, sweated, rode and lived with the troops. It is a reflection of what they went through as people, not just reporters. It is a snapshot of the relations they developed with their military counterparts." Disc 1 features stories related to the US Army and US Air Force.

From the program introduction: "These are personal stories of some of the men and women of ABC News who dug, ducked, ran, sweated, rode and lived with the troops. It is a reflection of what they went through as people, not just reporters. It is a snapshot of the relations they developed with their military counterparts." Disc 2 features stories related to the US Marines Corps and US Navy.

did.unittitle: The Media and Human Rights (Tape No. 1)
The Media and Human Rights (Tape No. 2)

scopecontent.p: This three day event produced by KCI and staged in conjunction with the 250th anniversary of the University of Pennsylvania features panel analysis of the post-Cold War world. Day 1, titled "After the Cold War", features discussion of the transformations in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and the global repercussions of the end of the Cold War. Day 2, titled "The New Global Marketplace", features discussion of the economic transformations in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and the emergence of global capitalism. Day 3, titled "Culture in the Communications Age", features discussion on the transformations in culture, technology and communications.

A sizable chunk of the material collected hereabout 30-40 tapesrelates to the University of Pennsylvania montage/feature included in the show (campus highlights and interviews related to U of Penn); these are primarily field tapes and post production materials. In addition to 20-25 tapes of collected clips/bump reels used for the produced segment pieces, the collected production material also includes camera original field tapes of interviews with Kissinger, Walter Mead, Lee Kwan Yew and others featured on the programs (about 20-30 tapes). Camera original footage and masters (multiple cameras, multiple locations) from the broadcasts/debates includes 20-30 tapes. Edited versions of segments, masters, protection copies and other post-production elements (graphics and audio) comprise 40-45 tapes. There are D2 digital tape masters available for all three segments.

altformavail.p: Many of these videotapes have been transferred to digital format, including the rough-cut submasters from the live event (ISO reels). Digitized items are noted in the inventory below.

scopecontent.p: Report on defense economics considers the position of the incoming presidential administration in light of the inherited and unsustainable levels of defense spending established during the Reagan defense boom. Options for reducing defense spending are outlined. Report features interviews with experts in the field of defense economics as well as footage of defense systems during manufacture and deployment.

scopecontent.p: This magazine program was a collaboration between Oregon Public Broadcasting and the ABC News Nightline unit. Anchored by Michel Martin, each episode presented 3-5 segments centered on a single theme. Episodes were created by independent producers and PBS stations, with editing and post-production work accomplished through the Nightline unit.

Holdings for this program include tape dubs in various formats of the following episodes/segments (multiple copies of most): "A Place in Time", "Flying", "Food", "Junk", "Leaving Home", "Milestones", "Money", "Roots", "Six Degrees of Separation", "Voice", and a rough cut "Highlights Reel".

WAER radio, Syracuse University. Ted Koppel student work at Syracuse University. Radio drama narrated by Ted Koppel (with Irish brogue). "Frank Melton's hearse...." WAER student production. Begins mid-narrative

WAER radio, Syracuse University. Ted Koppel student work, senior year at Syracuse University. Report on life in the Soviet Union, Soviet perceptions of the United States, etc. Compiled from tapes made during a two week stay in Moscow. Includes interviews with Ed Sullivan, Gov. Davis (North Dakota), Gov. McNichols (Colorado), Gov. Clyde (Utah), and various Russian citizens at the American Exhibition in Moscow

WAER radio, Syracuse University. Ted Koppel student work, Syracuse University. WAER classical music show "Allegro". Music with two short announcer breaks. Announcer identified as "Windy Craig" presumed to be Ted Koppel

KZSU radio, Stanford University. Ted Koppel student work. Mostly music (Bobby Vee, Frank Sinatra) with 1 brief announcer/disc jockey break. Announcer identified as "Marty", presumed to be Ted Koppel. Tuesday evening, March 7, Winter Quarter, 1961
